item.label: fresh
item.content: A hip indie version of Truffaut's Day for Night, Living in Oblivion celebrates the very act of filmmaking as grand folly, a triumph of absurdist heroism.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A treat.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A very funny picture that presents the world of independent film making as a nightmare of conflicting egos, budgetary squalor and incompetence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Oblivion\" has a surrealistic, guilty-fun quality. It feels almost too good to be true.

item.label: fresh
item.content: So you wanna make a movie? Well, first, you should see \"Living in Oblivion,\" Tom DiCillo's savagely funny satire of the world of independent filmmaking.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This feminist comedy shot through with fantasies about the travails of newly single womanhood strikes some rich chords, but doesn't quite put together a complete tune.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A new low in lame spoofery.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This film is stale.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A buddy cop parody of the lowest possible caliber.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The thematics are rather cloying, but the mood -- profoundly relaxed, bemused -- eventually conquers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [It's] loaded with wry, offbeat humor and is the sort of satisfying, personal picture that is becoming an increasingly rare commodity these days

item.label: fresh
item.content: Forsyth cannot quite tease out of his characters the kind of strange sublety that Powell and Pressburger delivered, but it is enough that he and producer David Puttnam succeed in making you realise just how badly this kind of film has been missed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Here is a small film to treasure, a loving, funny, understated portrait of a small Scottish town and its encounter with a giant oil company.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It demonstrates Mr. Forsyth's uncanny ability for making an audience sense that something magical is going on, even if that something isn't easily explained.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's cliched, ridiculous, and very entertaining.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The tag-team of filmmakers seems to have only two ideas - having stupendously ugly characters shove their mugs into the camera, or staging action sequences so dizzily you have no idea what's going on.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Does a fine job of continually coming up with obstacle after obstacle for our two leads to dodge - not the least of which happens to be good, old-fashioned logic.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Lockout\" is meat-and-potatoes filmmaking at its most basic.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's the kind of movie where someone tumbling in space above the earth's atmosphere opens a parachute and lands gently on earth without even gasping for a breath.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It does a splendid job of putting the pale into imitation and draining the life out of derivative.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's cheap, and then there's this rip-off.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Most of the time \"Lockout\" is pleasant enough, not something to recommend to a friend, but enjoyable in the moment.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mostly \"Lockout\" is lost in space.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A putrid film that comes dead-weighted with hammy one-liners and a plot so silly it borders on comedy...

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Lockout\"...is...as dopey an entertainment as imaginable, but it's also a reminder that the film's star, Guy Pearce, has always had great screen magnetism, to which he has now added a bedrock of muscle. Also: he can act.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If he's poking fun at the genre, Besson has a way to go, thanks to the distractions of a muddled story and silly ending that defies physics and all the laws of nature.

item.label: fresh
item.content: First-time writer-directors James Mather and Stephen St. Leger have put some thought into all of this - always a bonus in a no-brakes thriller, especially one of Besson's.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Lockout\" never busts out of its cheesy concept.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Lockout is genre all the way. The film wears its colors proudly, but it also, alas, wears out its welcome.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The editing by Eamonn Power and Camille Delamarre appears to have been handled while running from one gate to another in an airport somewhere.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I kept waiting for Nicolas Cage to show up. Or Katherine Heigl. Or, god forbid, both.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pearce gets into his groove swiftly, owns it and remains entertaining. The rest of the movie, however, would work better as a video game.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Too serious to be a parody and too stupid to be a viable action pic, Lockout floats like space junk in the final frontier.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I was thoroughly entertained while I was watching it, and I haven't hated myself since. And that is something, though I don't know exactly what.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Expect plenty of laughs and some edge-of-your-seat sweats, but not a whole lot else.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The best one can say is that it's a smart cartoon, and a fairly exhausting viewing experience.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Even if flashy Ritchie's tall tale about the East End underworld starts to run out of steam, the punch line is so good that it makes up for a lot.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels is the laborious title of an even more laborious Cockney action movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film had me alternating between a sugar high and drowsiness. One minute, I struggled to keep awake; the next, I was jumping in my seat. Neither extreme is particularly pleasurable.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Guignol violence, Lock, Stock aspires to be something like the Beatles meet the Wild Bunch. Too bad it doesn't have even a rubber soul.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The punchy little flourishes that load this English gangster film with attitude are perfectly welcome, because there's no honest, substantial part of the movie they can hurt.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film's lures, while undeniable, are synthetic, and we never do learn what fuels all the greed besides pints of beer.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The cast is revved up to sizzle, with Sting in a smallish role, and the thick cockney dialogue is more comprehensible than you might think.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An MTV-generation Peckinpah, Ritchie stages the splatter with a hideous giddiness. He's one to watch.

item.label: rotten
item.content: We've heard it all before, and usually with a slightly more comprehensible accent.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Lock, Stock is fun, in a slapdash way; it has an exuberance, and in a time when movies follow formulas like zombies, it's alive.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This may be the first movie to capture the reckless exuberance of Pulp Fiction without seeming like a blatant rip-off.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Go see it if you're in the mood. You're bound to get a chuckle, but don't expect too much.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A numbing combination of sloppy writing, vulgar art direction, high school acting, and bungled special effects.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Fundamentally, this is just further proof of Hollywood's untiring ability to reduce all science fiction to its most feeble stereotypes.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Harmless fun enlivened by a couple of sequences that are as good as the entire film should have been.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Run Lola Run is fun, fun, fun.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Cleverly juggling the elements and encounters of a simple thriller scenario by using multiple viewpoints and a domino effect to create different destinies...

item.label: fresh
item.content: Not only does Lola run, she takes this hyperkinetic pop culture firecracker of a film with her.

item.label: fresh
item.content: We get fast and slow motion, crane shots, split screens, handheld cinematography, tracking shots, lateral wipes, jump cuts, candy coloring, MTV-style editing, whip pans, still photographs and rapid-fire montages. You name it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A low-budget no-brainer, Run Lola Run is a lot more fun than Speed, a big-budget no-brainer...

item.label: fresh
item.content: Interspersed with Lola's zigzag swiftness are moments when the action shifts into trancelike tableaux.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Run Lola Run's power isn't in celebrating the giddy mixture of testosterone, drugs and new youth culture (i.e., electronica), but in taking the oldest of questions...

item.label: fresh
item.content: Run Lola Run is the feverish, wish-fulfillment embodiment of everyone's unspoken dream...

item.label: fresh
item.content: Run Lola Run is more than the sum of its gimmicks: It has a real worldview.

item.label: fresh
item.content: FAST, smart and fun,

item.label: fresh
item.content: A madly spinning top of a movie.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: A film of nonstop motion and visual invention.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's such a mopey, navel-gazing affair that even Gerwig has a hard time saving it.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Lola Versus is all Greta all the time, a bonanza for fans and proof that Gerwig's easy offbeat charm, obvious smarts and physical comedy gifts can carry a film.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's a Fitzgeraldian sense of generational malaise in all of this, but \"Lola Versus\" is convinced that it's hilarious.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a wonder Gerwig manages to keep the character endearing instead of grating, but she does.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Gerwig remains one of the most captivating new stars to hit the big screen, but she's still looking for a movie that deserves her.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Screenwriters Daryl Wein (who also directed) and Zoe Lister Jones give Gerwig very little to do other than to be Gerwig.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's funny, sweet, wise and even a little life-affirming.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Too self-conscious, too slight, too few insights.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The self-pitying Lola, alas, is only sporadically interesting...

item.label: rotten
item.content: An unfinished portrait of an unfinished womanchild with fidgety poise nicely embodied by Gerwig.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A well-intentioned indie that tries to be a \"real\" version of a Hollywood romantic comedy and ends up feeling more ersatz than ever.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Lola Versus\" takes the Lego-piece building blocks of a New York City relationship comedy and turns it into something more asymmetrical and ironic and interesting.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Unfortunately, Lola lives in a sitcom that deprives her of any intrinsic interest.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a sweet little diddle of a movie that doesn't make the mistake of tying everything up in a big bright bow.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: [It] transcends being just another chick flick and becomes an exploration of a subject that should ring true for just about every female viewer: the relentless narcissism of the friend who makes everything about her.

item.label: rotten
item.content: In spite of its scruffy look and slack pacing, it often rings as false as any of the big, shiny and soft studio rom-coms (starring Kate Hudson or Katherine Heigl, say) of the last decade.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gerwig is ... distinctive and interesting an actress to watch, especially when the story includes a lot of raw truth-telling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A movie that aspires to be deep but never gets out of the shallows even with a wonderful actress in the lead...

item.content: Where Nabokov was witty, Kubrick is sometimes merely snide, but fine performances (particularly from Peter Sellers, as the ominous Clare Quilty) cover most of the rough spots.

item.label: fresh

item.content: The picture has a rare power, a garbled but often moving push toward an off-beat communication.

item.content: It never stops worshiping Los Lonely Boys, the Texas trio made up of the brothers Henry, Jo Jo and Ringo Garza, long enough to feel genuine, as is evident from the frequent appearances of Kevin Wommack, the group's manager.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although it often plays more like a feel-good infomercial than a substantial cinematic portrait, Los Lonely Boys: Cottonfields and Crossroads scores a pleasing impact with spirited live performances.

item.content: Travolta gives a hangdog performance as the world-weary cop obsessed with rooting out the killers. Hayek and Leto share a few tart black comic moments as the film spirals into a bloodbath.

item.content: Strongly focused when it comes to atmosphere. But it strains too hard to contain its disparate plot elements.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Looking for Eric is a pleasant surprise -- somehow both ambitious and easygoing, funny and worrisome.

item.label: fresh
item.content: At times it falls flat, or fails to rise. More often than not, though, it's a heartbreaker.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Beginning in grim kitchen-sink territory, the movie gets lighter and goofier as it goes, and if it's a bit of a mess, it's also a pick-me-up that suggests how hard and how rewarding it can be to set a life back on course.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Cantona, big and bearded, is a genial Gallic guru. It's hard not to be swayed by his optimism, his sagacity, his generosity. And the optimism and generosity of Loach's film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Loach can't resolve this picture's contradictory impulses, but he has made the most entertaining sports film in a while. And I didn't know Cantona from a can of gray English peas.

item.label: fresh
item.content: And the film's riotous climax deftly turns grim social realism into action-slapstick revenge farce. Not something Mr. Loach has tried before, and something he turns out to do rather well.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A mashup of Nick Hornby and Martin Scorsese? Why not?

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's a kitchen sink full of dirty dishes that don't match.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's sweet, with lots of carpe diem talk, but it'll probably help if you have sports posters on your wall (and can translate a thick Mancunian accent).

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's about low-rent failures who survive by finding optimism through humor and friendship. It's uneven, but its optimistic message -- lost causes can find strength through friendship and bonding -- is contagious.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Capable of lifting even the stoniest heart.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Looking for Eric\" should connect with moviegoers who enjoy clever comic writing with a touch of fantasy plus fans of any sport that has legendary heroes. It looks set to be Loach's biggest mainstream hit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Pacino's first film as writer/director is a marvellously intelligent, witty and imaginative exploration of the problems faced by anyone wishing to act in Shakespeare or translate the plays to film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There are actors' rehearsals and performances, and Mr. Pacino interviews experts, conducts man-on-the-street polls and stages collegial arguments with his cronies. Thus emerges the intricate story of Richard's ambition.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The last half-hour drags.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An astute, funny, loving and occasionally even beautiful documentary about actors preparing to do a play.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Pacino makes looking for Richard a great adventure and outrageous fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While there's no harm in attempting to make Shakespeare more accessible, it's hard to imagine this film exciting anyone except Pacino's fans and those who are fatally charmed by celebrity actors.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Having chosen to be actors, they know they cannot respect their craft without embracing its greatest writer. Having chosen to be readers and viewers, we cannot do less, and this film is a delightful inspiration.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's ironic that the movie is done in by what you'd expect to be the high point: the performance segments that dominate the final third.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is a great idea for a sketch, not a feature, and if Heckerling had resisted padding it out, it might have made a brilliant short. A comedy can ride only so far on high concept. It has to deliver the jokes, and this one doesn't.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This fairly unlikely idea for a movie turns into a warm and lovable comedy, although I still don't think it needed the voiceovers from the baby.

item.content: This film has little to recommend itself.

item.content: It's a realistic take on what happens when high-flying money speculators suddenly hit ground. It's also a great calling card for J.C. Chandor, the writer/director making his feature debut.

item.label: fresh
item.content: That Chandor manages to find the blood in each character is accomplishment enough; that he manages to make his drama both relevant and timeless portends a bright future indeed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Margin Call is the movie Oliver Stone tried to make with Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps, only a lot less flashy and melodramatic -- and sharper, smarter and with a much stronger cast.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A terrific piece of entertainment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Margin Call is one of the strongest American films of the year and easily the best Wall Street movie ever made.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Chandor's film is not a tale of the plots and counterplots of conniving bankers. It is a disaster movie, in which even the Masters of the Universe are running for their lives.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Writer-director J.C. Chandor then plunges us into a dark night of quietly nasty reckoning as it becomes clear to the firm's honchos that the calamitous risk assessments one of their own was working on might well be true.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The real strength of '[Chandor's] debut feature is how persuasively it depicts the fishbowl world of high finance, whose executives seem incapable of seeing past their towering salaries and privileged lives.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's all fairly entertaining but also confusing for anybody who doesn't get the Wall Street lingo.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It sees its characters not as villains but, simply, as business people - with all that means.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though fictionalized and understated, \"Margin Call'' effectively voices the same outrage that the Occupy Wall Street movement is so loudly proclaiming.

item.label: fresh
item.content: How good is J.C. Chandor's debut? So good I was ready to buy what he was selling even though I didn't entirely understand it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A taut, smart and remarkably timely thriller...

item.content: It's very pretty and occasionally amusing but also dreadfully dull for long, long stretches.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The director squanders a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to film on the grounds and inside the Palace of Versailles. It's the trappings we get, in richly reproduced costumes and all-over gilt furniture, at the expense of any substance.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Little happens for much of Marie Antoinette, but Coppola is a visual storyteller, and with her first big canvas she creates a giddy world at Versailles in color and light.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Coppola's queen experiences no inner transformation or redemption because, in this telling, she's in no need of it. She's cool to begin with.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With lyrical intelligence and scrappy wit, Coppola creates a luscious world to get lost in. It's a pleasure.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is just a lark, a heavy-handed one without the heart of even the bad histories which gave us a Marie who said (as she never did) Let them eat cake.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Dunst plays Marie Antoinette as if she's seen the future and it's Paris Hilton.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Instead of turning her inside out, Coppola illustrates just how ordinary she was and how her insular world prevented her from understanding the events that eventually would end her life.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's not much meat at this banquet, only sweets.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Here's one thing about Marie Antoinette: It sure is easy to watch. And here's another: It's even easier to forget.

item.content: She was born into fabulous wealth and fame. By the time she was a teenager, her name was well-known to both the public and the well-to do. So is it any wonder Sofia Coppola wanted to do a movie about Marie Antoinette?

item.label: rotten
item.content: Although it is purposely devoid of substance, it is still devoid of substance.

item.content: By the end, the sad, preposterous emptiness of the court has overtaken the movie and turned it from a potentially intriguing drama into a forlorn, muzzy daydream.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie ends as it started, with Marie in a carriage, unaware of the fate we know awaits her. It's the last in a long line of things the movie neither shows or tells us.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Differing greatly from the rough, casual mood of many behind-the-scenes pop docs, this one is instead of a piece with Jackson's body of work: dazzling and strange, blurring the line between fantasy and reality.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Jackson's mystery deepens, even as it dissolves between our fingers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's fascinating, often in ways the people behind it might not have intended. It's shiny and slick and scary and cynical, and it's an epic portrait of all the contradictions in American celebrity culture and one of American culture's biggest celebrities.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This Is It is Jackson's moment to shine. For two hours, he's alive and kicking it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This Is It isn't quite extraordinary as non-fiction film goes. Perhaps it's something better: a work of generosity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Michael Jackson's This Is It is heartbreaking, exhilarating, baffling. In other words, it expresses the performer's persona in its purest form.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: This Is It isn't Michael Jackson at his greatest; it's him preparing to be at his greatest. But just watching that preparation is gift enough.

item.content: It is possible that the way to a new kind of musical -- using some of the talent and energy of what is still the most lively contemporary medium -- may begin with just this kind of musical performance documentary.

item.content: Grail is as funny as a movie can get, but it is also a tough-minded picture -- as outraged about the human propensity for violence as it is outrageous in its attack on that propensity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Silly, sophomoric, and slapped together -- but would you want it any other way?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Monty Python's Flying Circus, the British comedy group which gained fame via BBC-TV, send-up Arthurian legend, performed in whimsical fashion with Graham Chapman an effective straight man as King Arthur.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Python's delightful and, on the whole, consistent reductio ad absurdum of the Grail legend.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A marvelously particular kind of lunatic endeavor.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Holy Grail suffers from the same syndrome that afflicts many of these restored classics: It is better remembered than actually seen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For all its shenanigans, Monty Python and the Holy Grail has a sense of humor that is intellectual, even academic, at heart.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Really smart people improvising really silly gags and bits, most of which work, some of which don't.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Has been so quoted and requoted that the scenes and words feel tattooed onto the psychic membrane.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Still stands as a gloriously silly and twisted send-up.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Brimming over with unforgettable gags and baroquely nonsensical insults.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The new Holy Grail is no revelation, just hilarious confirmation that the old days were in fact better.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Still has the power to shock and make one laugh with shame.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An incredibly silly film of great humor, brilliant design and epic insanity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Represents one of the best and brightest comedies ever to shine from the silver screen.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I've always considered it the group's nadir; it seems toothlessly silly.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Just as wacky and imaginative as their earlier film outings.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Python successfully lampoon religious attitudes rather than religion itself.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bad taste of this order is rare but not yet dead.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The Pythons are enlightened jesters, whose scorn is reserved for those who persist in walking in darkness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Funny, in that peculiar British way where jokes are told sideways, with the obvious point and then the delayed zinger.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Still holds up beautifully, as both pointed satire and silly, stakes-free comedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I can't say Life of Brian stands as a comic masterpiece, but it's an indelible part of impolite cinema history, and some of its asides remain priceless.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A king-size cult comedy hit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Still has its rude, rowdy sting -- and it still speaks more truth about religion than nearly all serious movies on the subject.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The greatest work of religious skepticism ever put on the screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The more things change, the more we have to laugh if we are to have a prayer of remaining sane, and the Pythons are the best possible step in that direction.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a hearty burlesque.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Start calculating the costs to Lunar Industries of its singular form of devaluing, and Moon's central premise stops making sense.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A well-assembled sci-fi thriller.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Moon actually gets a little dull in the later reels, just when it should be peaking in mystery and tension.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An eccentric sci-fi which cleverly deconstructs the mythology of the Star Treks and Star Wars which have colonised the future of our imaginations with their glamour, self-importance and operatic sound tracks.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film is not entirely logical, but it raises pleasing questions and looks beautiful.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Most contemporary sci-fi movies come on with all CGI-guns blazing, trying to blow the roof off the theater. Moon settles for trying to blow your mind instead.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Storywise, Moon fails to live up to the promise of its premise. There's plenty of atmosphere, but little gravity.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For a 'paranoid thriller' to work, the paranoia has to rise and rise until a climax at the finale, not give away the game halfway in.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moon is first-rate science fiction, tackling such issues as identity, individuality and the effects of isolation on the psyche and the soul.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Watching Moon is kind of like seeing a booster rocket thrust seventies' sci-fi films deeper into orbit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Directed with a sure hand by Duncan Jones, Moon is the anti-Transformers, a science fiction tale that owes as much to fiction as to science.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With its artful use of old-school miniatures rather than computer graphics, Moon engages the eye as much as the mind. Here's a canny director who doesn't let technical prowess overwhelm his sure, resourceful sense of human drama and character.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The under-appreciated Rockwell finally gets a leading role -- make that roles -- worthy of his considerable talent.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In the end, Moon raises disturbing ethical questions about science and bioengineering, but it's the emotional questions the film poses -- about memory, about family, about identity -- that really resonate.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moon is closer to what die-hards expect when they hear the term 'sci-fi,' and its existence reminds us that serious movies within this genre are not dead -- they're just hiding.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It just may be the most boring movie ever made -- period.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As a piece of entertainment, Moon is a failed experiment. Yet though it never becomes enjoyable or gets even within hailing distance of fun, it has some interesting ideas.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Written and directed by the first-time director Duncan Jones, Moon devotes itself to the mystery of the multiplying Sams. It's a modest, melancholic undertaking, and a little virtuous, too.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Moonlight and Valentino is a Hallmark sympathy card of a film, pretty to look at with a message that's sincere. Yet it's hard to take its pretentious platitudes of grief and recovery too personally.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Christopher Wood's script takes the characters exactly where they always go in a James Bond pic and the only question is whether the stunts and gadgets will live up to expectations. They do.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Broccoli just keeps piling on the goodies: lush Ken Adam sets, gadgetry and gams galore, super stunts and effects.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Lewis Gilbert directed, but the real auteur of the series is production designer Ken Adam, whose spectacular chrome and plastic sets define Bond's world and technological ethic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The space-age plot is spread dangerously thin, the fights all tend to slapstick, and the wanton destruction has become rather too predictable. But it's held together by likeable performances.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moonraker is a movie by gadgeteers, for gadgeteers, about gadgeteers. Our age may be losing its faith in technology, but James Bond sure hasn't.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's one of the most buoyant Bond films of all.

item.label: fresh
item.content: While parts of Moonraker are rather silly, solid special effects, well-executed action sequences, and a strict reliance upon the 'Bond Formula' keep this film among Moore's better entries as the British superspy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Most of Wes Anderson's previous pictures came from the head; Moonrise Kingdom is one from the heart.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Anderson never loses his core themes - young love, the need to escape, the bind and bluster of family. His \"Kingdom\" may not be large, but it is perfectly appointed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Though undeniably smart and charming, \"Moonrise Kingdom\" loves itself the way the callow Holden Caulfield loves himself: unconditionally. Salinger understood the problem with that. Anderson may not.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Moonrise Kingdom\" takes place in a world where everything seems pleasantly faded, where people read crackly-covered library books rather than e-books, and where young people are allowed to be genuinely innocent.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The latest unadulterated delight from Wes Anderson, director of \"Rushmore,\" \"The Royal Tenenbaums\" and \"Fantastic Mr. Fox.\"

item.label: fresh
item.content: The usual complaints and caveats about Anderson - he's precious, his characters have no grounding in the real world - can be made about Moonrise Kingdom, but so what?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Anderson and his actors are able to convey more genuine feeling through these devices than most filmmakers can with more-traditional means.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One knock against some of Anderson's previous efforts is that they're too clever - so clever, in fact, that the humanity gets sucked out of them. That doesn't happen here.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Anderson's best feature since Rushmore, in part because, like that film, it takes as its primary subject matter odd, precocious children, rather than the damaged and dissatisfied adults they will one day become.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's no denying the extravagant pleasures \"Moonrise Kingdom\" affords as an erudite wish-fulfillment fantasy of empowerment and autonomy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Last time out, in Fantastic Mr. Fox, Wes Anderson adapted a children's book by Roald Dahl. Now, in Moonrise Kingdom, he's made one of his own.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's an adventure, a love story, a biblical allegory complete with approaching storm, a mash note to composer Benjamin Britten and a profoundly touching discourse on the needs of troubled children.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Moonrise Kingdom\" is Anderson's seventh movie, and it's the first since \"Rushmore\" that works from the opening shot to the final image.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Like all Wes Anderson movies, it is naive, mannered, pretentious and incomprehensible.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Wes Anderson's mind must be an exciting place for a story idea to be born.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Hayward and Gilman are newcomers who are asked to carry much of the film and pull it off with lovely understatement and extraordinary believability.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Its moments of transporting beauty and visual brilliance overcame my growing aversion to Wes Anderson's brand of ultra-stylized archness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: We may look back on Anderson's works as we do on the boxes of Joseph Cornell -- formal troves of frippery, studded with nostalgic private jokes, that lodge inexplicably in the heart. In Moonrise Kingdom, that lodging is already under way.

item.label: fresh
item.content: John Patrick Shanley's witty, shapely script puts an octet of New Yorkers under a lunar-tuney spell one romantic night. Cher shines brightest of all.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Norman Jewison's film is a mostly appetizing blend of comedy and drama carried by snappy dialog and a wonderful ensemble full of familiar faces.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Most of the show belongs to Cher and Cage, both of whom are at their energetic best.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Stronger on mores than amore, a half smile for a summer night.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The title refers to one relative's theory that the full moon can make people wildly romantic, make them behave in wonderful, unpredictably crazy ways. Not crazy enough.

item.label: fresh
item.content: They're an irresistibly offbeat couple -- Cage playing on the edge, where he likes it; Cher creating a fairy-tale realist, captivating yet cautious.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Reviews of the movie tend to make it sound like a madcap ethnic comedy, and that it is. But there is something more here, a certain bittersweet yearning that comes across as ineffably romantic, and a certain magical quality.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This ultra-mild frolic follows the 'fish-out-of-water' comedy formula so closely its lack of surprise is almost, well, surprising.

item.label: rotten
item.content: One of those cookie-cutter romantic comedies in which fish out of water (\"Which one's skim?\" Parker asks while milking cows) learn to swim together again.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie is like a car wreck in which no one is injured but the onlookers.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's a scene where Hugh Grant confronts a grizzly bear and I've never rooted so hard for a predatory mammal.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The cast is in such fine form that everything seems funny.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While it fails on nearly every conceivable level, as a textbook case in everything contemptible in the studio system, Did You Hear About the Morgans? is as good as it gets.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a pity there's no witness protection program for movies that commit crimes against audiences.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I grant you Hugh Grant and Sarah Jessica Parker evoke charm in the right screenplay. This is the wrong screenplay.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Hugh Grant and Sarah Jessica Parker are assigned to a witness protection program, flown to Wyoming, and installed in a one-horse town where there are no bistros, art galleries, department stores, or funny jokes.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Most bad comedies plod from scene to scene. This one plods from sentence to sentence. Grant and Parker stand around as if they're waiting for someone to yell, \"Cut.\"

item.label: rotten
item.content: Grant has never been less charming and Parker never less fashionable or more grating than they are as Paul and Meryl Morgan.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you are expecting a pleasant evening of escapism, you will be cruelly fooled. The editor responsible for the trailer is clearly a genius.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Hugh Grant and Sarah Jessica Parker ply their cute trademarks (his befuddled British grimace, her la-di-da New York sass) like grim, incompatible partners in a Hollywood business deal.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Cliche-ridden, stereotype-stuffed and clunky at every inevitably false turn, it's so bad that star Hugh Grant, usually the most relaxed of actors, actually seems to be in pain throughout the film.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Yes, comedies thrive on broad strokes. But selling Americans lame images of one another as if we haven't traversed the country (if not in actuality, via television and film) is dispiriting.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A comedy with mostly likable, broadly drawn characters; tart, nonthreatening social satire with sharp enough teeth to leave an impression while not breaking the skin; and well-timed, modestly sophisticated repartee.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Did you hear about the Morgans? If so, you might wish you hadn't.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Everything in this movie, written by Aline Brosh McKenna and directed by Roger Michell, seems way off.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This production is a mess for many reasons, most of them having to do with its frantic efforts to be funny.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Morning Glory is a tart, terrific comedy that gives Harrison Ford his best and funniest role in years.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Has moments of sparkle, but the screenplay disappoints and the luminous Rachel McAdams overdoes it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: McAdams is typically effervescent here, but she can't rescue this weak comedy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Morning Glory isn't terrible. It has a lot of craft, a lot of star power, and a fair number of laughs. What irks me is that the filmmakers settle for so little.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [McAdams's] Adorability Quotient is off the charts. If being ingratiating is a crime, she'd be shot at sunrise. But this good nature doesn't seem forced.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Morning Glory isn't targeting the dumbing down of TV news. It's pandering to the audience that craves the dumbness

item.label: rotten
item.content: Everyone involved here is operating well below his or her skill level.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It is what it's about - kissing frogs for ratings, entertainment that panders to the lowest common denominator.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This charmless movie thinks it can soft-sell its date-night love story and its media meta-jabs without people feeling they've been bamboozled on either count. To which we can only say good night, and good luck.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [A] generally woeful comedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Despite the conventional manner in which the story is resolved, Morning Glory generates enough entertainment, good will, and genuine laughs to make it hard to dislike.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Morning Glory is ultimately something of a morning news show version of a morning news show -- perky, jerky, chit-chatty and polished. And eminently, pointedly, forgettable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It includes more than a few clever lines, and boasts a stellar cast, including the underutilized Diane Keaton.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ford is the most casual he's been since Working Girl. When he and McAdams spar, you can't help but tune in.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie does show some welcome wit as it satirizes the idiocies of morning TV -- until it starts repeating itself in the second half.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Precious little rings true.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For the most part, Morning Glory is a delicious movie that will make you jump for joy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Where others have sunk in the mire of imitation, director Paul Anderson and writer Kevin Droney effect a viable balance between exquisitely choreographed action and ironic visual and verbal counterpoint.

item.label: fresh
item.content: British director Anderson does a fair job with what he was given: four good-looking leads, some very impressive sfx, Babylonian sets, a bone-crunching soundtrack, and a battery of well-choreographed fights.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The most intriguing is a glassy-eyed follower whose right hand shoots out a hissing reptile that can extend itself for miles. Exotic creatures like these make watching Mortal Kombat feel like being in a high-tech fun house.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Likely to satisfy only the core audience already hooked on video and arcade games, and even that's not a sure thing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie has everything a teenage boy could want... Everything, that is, but an interesting plot, decent dialogue and compelling acting.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie that most nearly approximates a video game: lots of action, no plot, eye-catching computer effects and a dollop of violence.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Just looks and plays a lot like Johnny Mnemonic, Double Dragon and other video-game-inspired, mayhem-filled messes.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moscow would be in a lot of trouble without a superbly sensitive portrayal by Robin Williams of a gentle Russian circus musician who makes a sudden decision to defect while visiting the US.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Where it scores so highly is not only in its ability to evoke Vladimir's astonishment at the bizarre, sometimes brutal texture of New York life, but also in the generosity it extends to the musician's sad predicament.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It made me feel good to be an American, and good that Vladimir Ivanoff was going to be one, too.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. Mazursky's fictional conceits do not do justice to Vladimir or to his situation, either in the Soviet Union or this country.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is that rare thing: a franchise that grows more winning with each instalment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: From time to time the improbable occurs: A sequel outdoes its original.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The screenplay, by Eric Darnell and Noah Baumbach, churns out the snappy witticisms with admirable creative gusto, but it whizzes along at such a frenetic pace that you'll probably miss half of them.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A fun and fast family entertainment.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The clever lines and themes of friendship and finding home are almost completely overwhelmed here by the breathless pace and sensory overload...

item.label: rotten
item.content: What might be barely tolerable in a seven-minute short gave me the biggest headache since \"Transformers: Dark of the Moon.''

item.label: fresh
item.content: [It] may be the best of the bunch, simply because it busts the leash that tethers it to anything resembling reality.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Set at a frenzied pace meant to connote fun, it mostly feels like a frenetic spectacle.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Kids will be stimulated. And, parents, you'll enjoy the sights.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A neon-saturated, high-flying trapeze act with enough frenetic funny business that it's a wonder the folks behind this zillion-dollar franchise about zoo critters on the lam didn't send the animals to the circus sooner.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Your brain goes breathless and giddy struggling to keep up.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I have to give props to a movie that ascends from eccentricity to insanity without losing its footing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's silly, and it's lazy. And yet, again, it's pretty funny.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Argento is admired for his voluptuous use of color and his operatic bloodletting; this is lovely to look at, if you can stand to.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mother of Tears may not stand tall in Argento's body of viscera-laden work, but this final chapter of a loosely defined trilogy is refreshingly old school in its trashiness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Aside from being vile and repellent, it's mainly dull -- old-fashioned in its shock tactics and culminating in a ho-hum climax.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The visuals are vibrant and fans of Argento's bravura bloodletting will thrill to his imaginative use of pikes, entrails and his daughter, who performs a shower scene for Dear Old Dad.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In The Mother of Tears, the last installment of the 'witch trilogy' that began, three decades ago, with Suspiria, an excavated urn unleashes a torrent of homicidal madness in Rome.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The gore is simply midnight-movie disgusting. And the ending is rushed and flat -- as if it had been tacked on by another hand.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film lacks the visual class of previous Argento efforts and relies more on shocks than suspense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Much of this spooky-spirits-in-Rome chiller is by the numbers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although The Mother of Tears teeters on the preposterous and awkward, it is diverting and reveals that the filmmaker's signature bravura flourishes and use of sinister settings are still intact.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mother of Tears transcends camp without forsaking it. Argento pitches the proceedings toward the ridiculous (his pacing is as perfect as some of the witches' breasts are fake) but only in the name of reaching a new cheesy sublime.

item.label: fresh
item.content: ...Silly, awkward, vulgar, outlandish, hysterical, inventive, revolting, flamboyant, titillating, ridiculous, mischievous, uproarious, cheap, priceless, tasteless and sublime.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The final installment of filmmaker Argento's Three Mothers series, this rollicking scarefest boasts roving bands of leggy witches, blundering priests, and voices from Beyond.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Italian director Dario Argento is revered by hard-core horror fans for his gothic, over-the-top thrillers, but even the patience of his most devoted followers will be sorely tested by Mother of Tears: The Third Mother.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Dario Argento's ketchupy brand of horror hasn't aged well, nor have his sexual politics. Enjoyably campy at first, then offensive and ultimately just bad.

item.label: rotten
item.content: That old Argento black magic, literally and figuratively, is still AWOL.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A once-great director's near-worst work passes through its funhouse plumbing and emerges from the crapper as intentional mischief: self-sabotage explained away as mad genius.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This deliciously wicked slice of demonic horror from Italian master Dario Argento serves as a devilish antidote to bleak shockers like Saw.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although lacking helmer's usual aesthetic panache, this Mother is a cheesy, breathless future camp classic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What keeps the whole thing from toppling into an abyss of unwatchable TV drama histrionics is a pair of dynamite performances from Annette Bening and Naomi Watts.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Obviously, this is emotionally rich ground and Garcia plows it perhaps a bit too heavily.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If Garcia's film never quite catches up with his ambitions for it, well, at least he's trying.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Garcia] lets the picture start to go soft in the middle, and teary melodrama floods in like water from a broken dam.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is well worth seeing for Bening's arresting, unpleasant performance.

item.label: fresh
item.content: So many stories come packaged in hyped genres that we can forget how much character can hold sway. Watts, Bening and Washington -- along with a fine ensemble and a humane director -- make sure we remember.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With Mother and Child, Garca brings his finely calibrated sense of drama to the subject of adoption, which he handles with characteristic restraint and insight -- at least until the film's maudlin, too-pat finale.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is an actors' showcase first, and clearly Garcia enjoys demonstrating what this ensemble can do.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film reminds us that character, not plot, is what binds us to a story. Cutting between scenes of each in her unique environment, the movie tantalizes us.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The fine actors show how we bond to those not related to us by blood -- and also how we love. Bring Kleenex.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A screenwriter's butterfly flaps its wings and a chain of events is set into motion, resulting in the latest cinematic ensemble tale of connectivity and yearning. This one's good, though.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Of all the performances, Samuel L. Jackson's is the most surprising. It sometimes appears that the busy Jackson will take almost any role to stay working. This film provides a reminder of his subtlety.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Dynamite performances from Annette Bening and Naomi Watts ignite this strong drama from writer-director Rodrigo Garcia.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you are a regular moviegoer who can't get enough of the daytime soaps, look no further than Mother and Child. It has enough soapy story lines to fill out at least three daytime series for a month.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's tough for actors to be nuanced when the movie isn't, and these intriguingly jagged edges soon get smoothed out.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mother and Child keeps the traffic moving smoothly, much more so than a movie like Crash, because Garcia writes characters rather than positions, and he knows that the silences between people usually speak louder than their words.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This movie's calm, steady control keeps a wide variety of good actors in the same universe.

item.label: fresh
item.content: You may not quite trust Mother and Child -- its soft spots and fuzzy edges give it away -- but you can believe just about everyone in it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Still, stellar actresses Annette Bening and Naomi Watts rise above every impediment, delivering memorably luminous moments as mother and child, separated at birth.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film is an actors' showcase that Bening makes the most of.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I wouldn't care if she was at the epicentre of the movement for global peace: she's a happily married mother who looks like Uma Thurman, and my reserves of sympathy are limited.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Whiny and self-involved, Thurman's mother of two sees judgment around every corner and believes the universe has conspired against her because the bakery misspelled her daughter's name on a birthday cake.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Motherhood gives upper-middle-class whining a bad name.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Unfortunately, nothing here digs too deep.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The humor is soft, the dramas are small, and the movie stumbles from loose and scruffy naturalism to sitcom tidiness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Uma, overload. Overload, Uma.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If Carrie Bradshaw ever trades her Manolos for sneakers and starts blogging about raising children, I pray she wouldn't be as tiresome as the heroine of Katherine Dieckmann's insufferable comedy Motherhood.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Motherhood] not only overdoes its premise, but it's hampered by several flaws. When it tries to be serious, it's too earnest, and when it tries to strike a chord, it's banal.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A pleasing, lighthearted look at the mommy wars.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Many films have been made about the perils of parenthood, but none with a more attractive and entertaining mom on the verge of a nervous breakdown than Uma Thurman in Motherhood.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You can see the movie wants to comment on all the frustrations of urban motherhood, but it does so only shallowly. How did having children kill Eliza's \"fiercely lyrical'' fiction career? The movie isn't that political or reflective.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Thurman is] quite funny, but her performance is at once winning and overstated.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A portrait of parenthood that's apt to turn one into an ardent advocate of contraception, Motherhood portrays such shrill, mopey and all-around unpleasant adults that it's hard to believe any of them found procreative partners.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Dieckmann nails the look of a certain niche of urban neo-middle-class living, but the film's hyper-earnest tone and reliance on \"day-from-hell\" New York cliches overwhelm those details.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Though pregnant with possibility, Motherhood fails to deliver.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As the mother, Nargis is as resolute as a force of nature, and Mehboob Khan creates tableaux of the family that evoke its fragile unity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: True, there are dull spots and the overripe supporting cast pale beside Nargis' 'force of nature' central performance, but overall it's a wallowy treat.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An outrageous masala of apparently discordant elements.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A serious drama that is also funny without crossing into burlesque.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Stuffed with secrets and characters who can't wait to betray one another, the film offers no one to root for except Mother, whose perverted family values at least remain consistent.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The ready crackle of [De Mornay's] studiously demonic performance brings welcome distraction from this otherwise crude litany of torture and wretched death.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Notable for a chilling lead performance from Rebecca De Mornay and not much else.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mother's Day is distinguished, at least, by De Mornay's porcelain-smile lampoon of castigating matriarchy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Undistinguished apart from Rebecca De Mornay's performance as an unhinged mama.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Excruciatingly misguided.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As absurd as its title, and by those standards it's a hilarious success.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A magnificent and deeply rewarding example of Bresson's stripped-down methods of cutting and framing, sound and dialogue, performance and movement.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like any genius, Bresson made rules in order to break them.

item.label: rotten
item.content: In artistically pointing up their lack of understanding and affection for Mouchette, Mr. Bresson never fully lets a viewer in on details that would help him appreciate them, too.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a remarkable film: dark, compressed, shattering.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Moulin Rouge is a tour de force of artifice, a dazzling pastiche of musical and visual elements at the service of a blatantly artificial story.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. Luhrmann and his colleagues have worked like whirling dervishes to make the plot look like it's moving.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If it lacks the emotional punch of Luhrmann's earlier films, and drags towards the end, it is still great fun.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Luhrmann] gives you way too much of what you didn't really want in the first place: soulless high jinks.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The net result of all this cinematic whirling, of the \"wrong\" music and of the parodic plot, is that nothing at all in the film moves us.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film dances; the heart sings.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A wonderful postmodern hug of a movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A magnificent mess of a postmodern musical.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The colors and songs all come together to form a movie that is like no other before it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: So cheeky, aggressive and bursting with vitality that it can't help being annoying and exhilarating at the same time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's all very festive, like a party you didn't really want to go to but then can't leave once you get there.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Disappointing because it could have been so much more.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Reconfigures bigscreen musicals with more daring, inventiveness and conviction than any movie since The Umbrellas of Cherbourg.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What pleasure Moulin Rouge produces must be weighed against brain cells sacrificed to such experimentation.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's torn between comedy and romantic melodrama.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A dazzling, electrifying event that transcends the screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie is more like the Moulin Rouge of my adolescent fantasies than the real Moulin Rouge ever could be.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Luhrmann has created his own spectacular, spectacular.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A film as unpredictable as the love it celebrates -- you keep falling in and out of this giddy affair.
