item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a not-bad gift for those who prefer their laughs black.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Despite all the gross-out humor, the most offensive thing about this is the lazy filmmaking; every shot feels like a first take, and the haphazard editing precludes any comic timing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It is utterly disgusting throughout.

item.label: rotten
item.content: How many directors does it take to screw in a star-studded piece of aggressive stupidity and call it a movie? An even dozen, and there is no punch line.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Deadly dull, unfunny, offensive, and stultifyingly clumsy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Once you're attuned to the movie's desperation to shock, you begin to have that jaded, ho-hum feeling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You won't believe how tiresome bad taste has become.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Your laugh mileage may vary (God forbid), but we can all agree on one thing: this is the biggest waste of talent in cinema history.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I see a bright future ahead for this sui generis work, which will be passed around sixth grade classrooms by odd-smelling kids for years to come.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An awesome array of talent doesn't prevent this witlessly profane anthology of comic shorts from being an utter disaster.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A gaping wound on the side of cinema, a January release that's yearning to be hidden from audiences, the ugly stinking maw of a Hollywood system that thinks you're an idiot.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Standing out amid an excellent cast is Elijah Wood, stymied by tweeness in the earlier films but here convincingly developing the character of Frodo as the embodiment of valor and self-sacrifice.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Some story strands are crudely abbreviated; others fail to develop elements that were already well-established.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Pops your eyes, excites your senses and brings you in as close as a whisper for scenes of startling emotion.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As I watched this film, an eager victim of its boundless will to astound, I found my loyal memories of the book beginning to fade.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Not only has Jackson boldly and faithfully brought J.R.R. Tolkien's world to life, he's created the most epic and sweeping fantasy adventure of all time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Completes the picture, magnificently so, and all honour and praise are due the visionaries behind the project.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The thrilling conclusion to what has become the film event of our time -- the definitive screen fantasy -- features more spellbinding moments, bigger battles, more emotion and more poetry than the terrific first two films in the trilogy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A movie for our time, perhaps for all time, mostly a good time and definitely a long time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It reminds you of the power of film like no other movie in memory.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I went along with the first and admired the second, but it wasn't until the third that I was swept away by the magnitude of Jackson's vision.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Confirms Jackson's reputation as a kinetic director who has made author J.R.R. Tolkien's work his own -- not as plagiarist but as a visionary.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Return of the King is such a crowning achievement, such a visionary use of all the tools of special effects, such a pure spectacle, that it can be enjoyed even by those who have not seen the first two films.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The final chapter completes The Lord of the Rings series in thrilling style -- and restores faith in the idea that popular entertainment can soar to majestic heights.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film event of the millennium.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is the best of the three Rings movies -- more than that, it makes the others look even better.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Not only a thrilling experience, it closes the book on a truly satisfying trilogy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tolkien and his representative on Earth, [Peter] Jackson, really know how to get a tale roaring down the tracks.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Insanely spectacular and never less than absorbing, The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King not only fully celebrates J.R.R. Tolkien's classic literary work but fully explains Jackson's outsized obsession with bringing it to the screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The director and screenwriter brings unity to a somewhat unwieldy story and handles the spectacle scenes with flourish and coherence.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The word trilogy, which was handed such a black eye by the Matrix movies, is restored to its proper dignity with Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A stunning example of a pure, disorienting dream logic that cinema provides all too rarely.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Palaces and shimmering lakes, warplanes and fire sprites all come to life at the breath of Miyazaki's graphic genius.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The risibly cloying closing scenes are likely to nix any remaining goodwill, blotting out such delicate early touches as a stroll through the air far above a town square.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There is giggling, belly-laughing, and gasping to be done watching Howl's Moving Castle.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Howl's Moving Castle moves -- in short, choppy, jumpy jerks that will never make anyone forget how fluid the truly great hand-drawn cartoons look by comparison.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With such an unfocused, impenetrable center, the film grows dull.

item.label: fresh
item.content: So richly detailed and colorful that one almost aches from the beauty.

item.label: fresh
item.content: If you've yet to take the anime plunge, this is a fine place to start; if you're an old hand, you will not be disappointed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The world it gives us to live in, for a couple of hours, is pure magic. It is one of those places we might wish never to leave.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Choppy story lines and threadbare characterization often hamper live-action adventures, and Mr. Miyazaki's newest anime endeavor suffers from similar handicaps.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The whole thing has the heavenly whimsy of Ludwig Bemelmans' illustrations from the classic French children's books.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An insanely creative work.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The procession of enchanting and spectacular images is intoxicating.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A feast of images and ideas for those who still cling to the idea that animation ought to be every bit as expressive as anything that begins with a blank page, a sharp pencil and an unharnessed imagination.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Meanders so listlessly that its details become less and less charming. Miyazaki's storytelling style resembles that of a breathless young tot who's fearlessly exercising his newfound powers of expression.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Miyazaki may not have achieved the level of Spirited Away, but he's still ahead of the curve.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Speaking of enchantment, that's the ultimate thing missing from Howl's Moving Castle. That and soul.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There is no story, or rather, there's no force to the story, which meanders almost casually this way and that for no apparent reason.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Miyazaki is like a soulful cartographer of the soul, mapping our inner landscape, leaving us bedazzled.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. and Mrs. Smith works on almost every level and against all odds.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The couple's dark, deadpan banter is amusing, particularly during a car chase in which they rapidly exchange some home truths. But there's a coldness to their characters that is never resolved.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Have we lost our minds and souls so completely to celebrity worship that drivel like Mr. and Mrs. Smith can thrive and prosper?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Very good.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The studio must have reasoned that Jolie and Brad Pitt are movie stars, so anything they do would be seen as fun and attractive -- and what could be more fun and attractive than their trying to kill each other and just about everybody else in the movie?

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a love story not for the faint of heart. In other words, it's a lot like marriage.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A movie so in love with itself it hardly needs us at all.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Who knows what went on behind the screen between Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt, but what's on the screen is extremely entertaining.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie look like they had a terrific time making Mr. and Mrs. Smith -- but I certainly didn't have a good time watching it. Neither, I suspect, will many of you.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. and Mrs. Smith will prove a long, hard slog for filmgoers who don't think that simply gazing at Pitt and Jolie constitutes a fun night out.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Essentially, Mr. and Mrs. Smith exists for the purpose of showing off the gorgeous faces and physiques of its two stars, and for giving its audience the dubious pleasure of watching them beat each other up.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A high-gloss, high-caliber domestic squabble, a lip-lock and load romance that might just as easily have been called 'Mr. and Mrs. Smith and Wesson.'

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. and Mrs. Smith is an awful movie with two very good-looking people in it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pitt and Jolie make sexy sparring partners, but they can't lift this leaden material.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's not perfect. It's like a marriage.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Their much-hyped kiss-kiss, bang-bang movie is an expensive time-waster, full of slow-motion explosions and big-scene payoffs that turn out to be duds.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's no real kick to all the wanton destruction, no sense of real thrill or peril, because the movie, which was written by Simon Kinberg (and rewritten, and then rewritten some more during production) chickens out.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A cute little romantic comedy buried under enough overblown action, gaudy firepower and special effects to fill a Jerry Bruckheimer picture.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This fractured Citizen Kane, built of frames within frames and mirrors within mirrors, is aptly brought to life by Welles's later style, born of low budgets and high anxiety, its grotesque closeups and cocked angles suggesting worlds and minds askew.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Engaging meller it may be, but missing the incisive delineation that marked Kane.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Failure or not, it's irresistible.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A film, which, for all its strangeness, is seldom less than brilliant.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For all of the film's perversity, there is greatness in it -- a greatness harshly criticizing itself.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The hilarious sting of the TV show is gone; only the rubber-faced shtick remains.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Atkinson's Mr. Bean, a man of few words, carries their memory in his rubbery bones. When it comes to knowing where he came from, he's got the beat.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For younger audiences, Mr. Bean's Holiday will be a pleasure, and of course, Bean addicts will, as always, be happy to see Atkinson's alter ego return to the big screen.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film, set mostly in France, pays homage to Jacques Tati, but the mostly silent gags feel like watered-down Bean.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Bean seems to lament how some filmmakers have forgotten that film is foremost a medium of mass entertainment. The great sadness is that without uttering much of anything, is a few jokes short of making a very good point.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The Wikipedia page on gurning lists Atkinson right behind Jim Carrey as one of the world's leading practitioners of grotesque face-making. And this is his ghastly masterpiece.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An only intermittently funny sequel that finally livens up in the last third. But that part -- a hilarious putdown of the pretension at the Cannes Film Festival -- is worth sticking around for.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film's Harold Lloyd-inspired slapstick may be infantile, but it has an innocent sensibility that is a nice counterbalance to the equally childish but prurient American Pie flicks.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For a silly kids movie about an accident-prone man on a trip to the beach, Mr. Bean's Holiday is actually quite mean-spirited and pretentious.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. Bean's Holiday picks up steam when it finally arrives in Cannes just in time to wreak yet more havoc at the big film festival, but getting there is pretty tedious. A little of the wildly mugging Atkinson goes a long way.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you've never been particularly fond of Atkinson's brand of slapstick, you certainly won't be converted by this trifle.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Don't mistake this simpleton hero, or the movie's own simplicity, for a lack of smarts. Mr. Bean's Holiday is quite savvy about filmmaking, landing a few blows for satire.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A refreshingly blunt reminder of the simple roots of comedy in these grim, overly manufactured times.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A throwback to silent movie clowns.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Somewhere, Jacques Tati is smiling.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Rowan Atkinson continues a tradition that in the right hands never gets stale: comic pantomime.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The humour in Mr. Bean's Holiday, more chucklesome than uproarious, doesn't feel particularly contemporary. It has the kind of simplicity that's most likely to appeal to either the old or young.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This wannabe highbrow horror-thriller is a graceless, unfocused piece of work with a central narrative as tonally schizophrenic and wayward as its lead.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. Brooks spins a web that will wrap you up in nightmares.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie is so well made, and so compelling as a portrait of a man at war with himself, that, right up until the end, many people will probably be entertained by its intricately preposterous story.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Director] Evans keeps flirting with a potentially rich idea only to surround it with indigestible amounts of silliness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Quite a few plot lines and character quandaries remain unresolved. And yet the movie makes sense as it stands. After all, one can never know what makes a psychopath tick.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Certainly more genuinely creepy than many recent thrillers, and the supporting cast is effective.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You know you're in real trouble when Demi Moore's playing the most sympathetic character you have.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Please don't tell me it was supposed to be played for laughs all along, because I don't buy it. Too late to save it from doom, the twists and snafus in Mr. Brooks start coming too fast for the audience to absorb, and the movie turns delusional.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In Mr. Brooks, Bruce A. Evans' fitfully subversive approach to the genre, we get a few fresh takes on the psychology of serial killing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Totally absurd and equally entertaining.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film emerges as a subtle commentary on a disquieting aspect of our current culture -- a commentary on the nature of a masturbatory voyeurism and how it fosters heartlessness by turning other people into objects.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The kind of movie that rockets so far beyond the line of credibility and so deeply into the realm of utter stupidity, you start to wonder if the filmmakers aren't putting you on.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I count a baker's dozen of movie plots here, a tally so impressive that the qualifier -- all of them are inane -- seems almost ungenerous.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Far-fetched, flimsy and uninvolving.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What starts out as a delightful black comedy and social commentary ends up, at best, as a guilty pleasure where I had a hard time sorting out the intentional from the unintentional laughs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Costner seems to be having some fun playing the respectable guy with an evil secret, but [director] Evans' murky storytelling just weighs him down. Cook has all the charisma of a misshapen mud pie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. Brooks has more tonal shifts than a Philip Glass concert, never deciding if it's a thriller, a noir, a comedy or a farce.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The star and his numbskull cronies piss on Capra's grave with acrid insincerity.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Let's cut to the consumer-advice bottom line: Stay home.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's not just that the movie itself is wicked awful, it's that Mr. Deeds brings out the worst in Adam Sandler.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's nothing funny about this.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The projectors in the theater practically shut down with boredom.

item.label: rotten
item.content: All in all, this baby makes you ever more eternally grateful for AMC and TCM on the cable. That's where the real movies have gone to hide.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You don't have to be a tree-hugging pacificist to be sickened by the constant sight of Sandler putting his fists and boots to someone, or of others imitating his psychotic behaviour.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's nothing more than a money maker for the filmmakers and a pointless star vehicle for Sandler.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A stink bomb of a movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The latest Adam Sandler assault and possibly the worst film of the year.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The otherwise good-naturedness of Mr. Deeds, with its embrace of sheer goofiness and cameos of less- than-likely New York celebrities ... certainly raises the film above anything Sandler's been attached to before.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. Deeds isn't bad for an Adam Sandler film, which is as backhanded as a compliment can get.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Anyone who has responded to the sweet side of Adam Sandler's growing comic screen persona is sure to be delighted by Mr. Deeds.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sandler is ready to be himself again, which means veering between his usual devilish savant and a newer post-adolescent gentleman.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A surprisingly funny movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Never decides whether it wants to be a surreal farce, a satire, a romance, an homage or all of the above.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It virtually defines a comedy that's strongly mediocre, with funny bits surfacing every once in a while.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Utterly predictable, thoroughly sentimental and -- worse -- not all that funny.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mostly terrible, a shambles of a comedy that looks as if it was shot by a tabloid news crew.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Since there are no recognizable humans in it, Mr. Hobbs is really strictly for the bird watchers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a fun picture, although it misfires, chiefly in the situation development department.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A wholesome family comedy with Stewart and O'Hara as a couple whose quiet vacation becomes a noisy free-for-all for the kids.

item.label: fresh
item.content: At a time when he easily could duck and cover, Spielberg has put himself at the service of material that offers little by way of comfort.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Spielberg is simply reiterating that the Old Testament demand of an eye for an eye has left the world blinded and wandering in an endless cycle of reprisal. This is not exactly a philosophical or dramatic revelation.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Bouncing about from one flawed movie to another, Steven Spielberg has lost his way of late, and Munich finds him more disoriented than ever.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Simply stated, Munich is Steven Spielberg's return to seriousness and his finest film in years.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An impressive achievement by a man in touch with his art and his soul.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A visceral, emotionally exhausting work that dares to ask questions -- and gives no easy answers.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Munich is an action movie with a conscience, made by a filmmaker whose good work is still better than most directors' best.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The problem with Munich is that Spielberg has made a beautifully crafted, intelligent picture that raises some very complicated, and not easily dismissed, moral questions -- only ultimately to find the easiest way to dismiss them.

item.content: Tykwer loses his cinematic grip when he tries to blend murder and piety. In his hands, the two don't emulsify.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer never tries to make Jean-Baptiste sympathetic but he's not rendered monstrous, either: He just is a victim of a passion larger and more powerful than any one man can handle.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [The filmmakers] render a portrait of Paris that both delights and overwhelms the senses. This is a movie where eyes turn into noses, which may run at the many ghastly sights presented.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tykwer, best known for the ultramodern chase movie Run Lola Run, would seem an unusual choice for a period film, but he infuses the sometimes stately story with vigor; though well past two and a half hours, it never feels long.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie talks suggestively about smells but can't quite find a way to bring them to life, so [director Tom] Tykwer uses images to rub our noses in as many disgusting things as he can.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie is lost. Whishaw succeeds in making the repulsive protagonist thoroughly repulsive, which is probably a testimony to his acting ability. But it doesn't make it anything worth watching.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Even if that broad interpretation -- that art is worth any human cost, that identity can be put on, like a scent -- leaves you cold, there's a world to immerse yourself in, a killer to be pursued, and an innocent to be feared for.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Lush visuals and lusty, rhapsodic language bring Perfume as close as cinematically possible to capturing an elusive sense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Perfume, a fast-paced allegorical tale about the pursuit of perfection, may fill the senses for its duration, but without a discernible psychological essence it does not linger for long.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Tykwer has to set a unique tone here -- fairy tales about serial killers being somewhat rare -- and he manages the absurdity of his subject matter well, keeping Jean-Baptiste right on the edge between monster and genius.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Director Tom Tykwer can be commended for capturing so much of the book's melange of pleasure, pain and longing for the impossible in Perfume, which is at least the most elegant movie yet made about the exploits of a serial killer.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Perfume reminds us that the line between masterwork and folly can be awfully thin. But the movie contains so many beautiful and unsettling moments that it earns a right to be seen, if not fully embraced.

item.label: fresh
item.content: So rich is the book's language about our scented world, it was difficult to imagine a movie capturing the texture of its remarkable and elusive character. Yet, Tykwer and his crew make pungent work of Grenouille's world.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Despite a fairly spectacular climax, the material's generic limitations eventually catch up with the plot.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The director stays true to the source novel even when it lifts into a magical realism that works only on the page, and his faithfulness betrays him. Perfume is a thriller that Hobbes might have envied.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It ventures so fearlessly down one limited, terrifying, seductive dead end, and finds there a solution both sublime and horrifying. It took imagination to tell it, courage to film it, thought to act it, and from the audience it requires a brave curiosity.

item.content: Every once in a long while, along comes a refreshing change like My Best Friend's Wedding, a movie whose appeal rests largely on its knack for defying our expectations by riffing off, even undermining, a familiar genre.

item.content: Roberts puts her heart into this one. Audiences are likely to return the favor.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Watching Norbit is like watching a train wreck with eye clamps on.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Norbit is another crude, sloppy paycheck job for an actor who doesn't need the money -- and who proved in Dreamgirls that he is capable of far better.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A quick paycheck may sound like a good idea when you're a creatively tapped comedian making trash like Daddy Day Care. But when you're a suddenly serious comeback kid aiming for an Oscar?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Although there's no denying the threadbare nature of the script, watching Murphy riff can be a formidable entertainment on its own.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Murphy looks like he's in pain, and he probably is -- latex cellulite can't be fun to wear -- but his anguish is as much existential as physical, trapped inside a lumbering vehicle that offers a morbidly obese harpy as the main comic attraction.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Norbit is pretty much a bad-taste sinkhole, with Murphy competing against himself to see which of his three characters he can make more grating.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Norbit may be the most disturbing, morally repugnant, nightmare-inducing film of the century so far.

item.label: rotten

item.content: The first lesson we learn in Scott Hicks' contrived romance No Reservations is that 'there's no greater sin than to overcook a quail.' The second is that a blandly seasoned comedy is nearly as unappetizing.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: To watch Nowhere Boy is to appreciate anew both the anger that drove Lennon and the strength of character it took for him to overcome it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The reason to see Nowhere Boy is the charismatic Johnson, who effortlessly nails Lennon's strut, anger and sensitivity. Anybody seeing the movie could surely spot a star in the making.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Taylor-Wood stresses the universals rather than the specifics of John's youth. So don't go expecting a Fab Four origin story. The word Beatles is never uttered. But do go.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: We reflect that even if all you need is love, that isn't always all you get.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Except for a few short bursts here and there, and one extended scene during the climax, the film is mostly talk. And since Van Damme's range as a dramatic actor is marginal at best, this is a problem.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Out of Africa is, at last, the free-spirited, fullhearted gesture that everyone has been waiting for the movies to make all decade long. It reclaims the emotional territory that is rightfully theirs.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Maybe the problem of the pacing is simply the nature of the beast these days with expensive period pieces. Once the difficult details are all in place, it may be too much to expect a director to resist milking every scene for more than it's worth.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sydney Pollack applies craftsmanship and restraint to a classic plot curve of longing, fulfillment, and loss, and although the denouement is a bit overextended, he never yields to facile, insistent sentimentality -- his effects are honestly won.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For all that it may come out of Africa, the film's final destination is not many miles from Disneyland.

item.label: rotten
item.content: With the exception of Miss Streep's performance, the pleasures of Out of Africa are all peripheral -- David Watkin's photography, the landscapes, the shots of animal life -all of which would fit neatly into a National Geographic layout.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Out of Africa is a great movie to look at, breathtakingly filmed on location. It is a movie with the courage to be about complex, sweeping emotions, and to use the star power of its actors without apology.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It tells a grand love story in less-than-grand fashion but is nevertheless worth seeing because of all the other things it does right.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Let us take a moment to praise two great and surprisingly powerful characters: a winged monkey and a wee girl made out of china. Because so much human wonder resides in these two creations of make-up, puppetry, digital effects and lovely performances.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Oz the Great and Powerful somehow manages to be both slavish to its hallowed template (when convenient) and completely tone-deaf to the magic that made it a one-of-a-kind cultural milestone.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Raimi's film is supposed to be about magic, but magic is in scant supply.

item.content: \"Oz the Great and Powerful\" will likely dazzle family audiences while satisfying movie purists. Somewhere over the rainbow there may be a more magical movie, but this will certainly do.

item.content: A visually over-crammed, emotionally empty mega-spectacle on the model of Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland.

item.content: Writer-director Daniel Barnz manages to achieve a true and delicate balance for much of Phoebe in Wonderland, his first feature, but ultimately undermines himself with heavy-handed and rather hackneyed whimsy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a rare thing when a labor of love turns out to be worth both the labor and the love.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It leaves you frustrated and annoyed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An uneven, unfocused amalgamation of ideas and moods that is at times deeply moving nonetheless.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's that kind of movie, full of therapeutic notions paraded as poetry and scenes that seem to carry explanatory labels.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Elle Fanning, and her audience, deserve better.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Phoebe in Wonderland gradually loses its grip on tone and believability, climaxing with a show-must-go-on moment that's just plain silly. Thankfully, Barnz knows exactly where to end his film: on the face of a girl, and an actress, at the crossroads.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Unfortunately, the film is insultingly soft in its portrayal of neurological disorders, linking the disease to Phoebe's fanciful conversations with characters from Alice in Wonderland.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Phoebe appears to have obsessive-compulsive disorder (or something), but Phoebe in Wonderland is so intent on celebrating her as 'special' that it quirks up the trauma of her issues.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The performances are transcendent -- especially Fanning's, as the little girl who wants to get better, who wants to be better, as she slowly disappears through the Looking Glass.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Barnz arbitrarily posits a nonsensical series of school \"rules\" to embody conformity, while imagination is repped by Tourette syndrome.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The mesmerizing performance of [Elle] Fanning as the gifted and troubled young Phoebe sparks the picture.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Performances are more mature, the soundtrack (by Nicholas Hooper) less grandiose, and Yates executes some thrilling set-pieces.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Brought me straight back to one of the most enduring of childhood feelings: boredom.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Installment five boosts his [Harry's] rebellion to enjoyable levels of British pique.

item.label: fresh
item.content: We do get terrific work from the all-star British cast, and the special effects are as seamless as ever.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Director David Yates, who is new to the Potter franchise, moves the story along briskly, at the expense of texture and nuance.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Truth be told, it's the lad's many onscreen allies that prove the film franchise's richest draws. (Thank you, Alan Rickman, for your wonderfully embittered turn as Severus Snape.)

item.label: fresh
item.content: Yates, especially given the sinister subject matter on hand, does a rather workmanlike job of traffic-managing the action. But some of the magic effects are indeed magical.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is the bleakest Potter installment to date, and under David Yates's choppy direction, Maggie Smith, Emma Thompson, Brendan Gleeson, and David Thewlis have little more than walk-ons.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The whole Hogwarts faculty is so beautifully cast, it reinforces the American impression that in Britain great actors must be piled up on the side of the road in heaps.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a gangly, confusing sprawl, and yet there are enough patches of beauty scattered throughout that it's impossible to reject it wholesale.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It seems that love and friendship are qualities worth rattling your wand over. En route, we can once more ooh-and-aah at the franchise's impressive array of acting talent.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There's still enough suspense built into the saga to keep us watching, but after five installments, this dazzling box office wizard is slowly running out of tricks.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Whatever happened to the delight and, if you'll excuse the term, the magic in the Harry Potter series?

item.label: fresh
item.content: To their credit, new director David Yates and new screenwriter Michael Goldenberg never lose the heart of the tale. Even in the midst of an incredibly thrilling magical battle of whippeting wands, flashing light and furor, they focus on Harry's inner war.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [The filmmakers] have transformed J.K. Rowling's garrulous storytelling into something leaner, moodier and more compelling, that ticks with metronomic purpose as the story flits between psychological darkness and cartoonish slapstick.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Continuing the increasingly darker, more adult trend of the series, the film version is swiftly paced, engrossing and often thrilling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Yates lacks a steady grip on the shape and rhythm of the film.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It all feels a little safe. The movie's full of spells, all right. But where's the magic?

item.label: rotten
item.content: A fruitcake-of-a-movie dense with exposition and woefully short on payoff.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Raises more questions than it answers as it attempts to convince us that a moralistic sniper would torture a sleazy publicist into tears of guilt and remorse over what amounts to a few paltry, venial sins.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If this sounds like a Kafkaesque spoof thrown together for the annual Publicists Guild of America luncheon, Larry Cohen's script is only occasionally that clever.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The premise is admittedly a killer -- fun to think about, fun to see realized, not so fun to see screwed up in the last half-hour.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A first-tier thriller, Phone Booth will make you think twice before you ever enter a public phone facility again, but while it curls your hair, it makes you think.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [A] taut thriller that hooked me from the outset.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A superficially gritty yet soullessly slick melodrama.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Anyone inclined to argue with the logic of the story -- and there's certainly much to argue about -- is advised to just sit back and watch how Farrell's Stu unravels before our eyes.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's cinematic flash, tarted up with gritty gray-blue lighting and gimmicky photography.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A movie that combines a seriousness of purpose with an impish delight in craft, in a way Hitchcock would have appreciated.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Its plot ... not only fully exploits Schumacher's strengths as a filmmaker but also has encouraged the director to keep things atypically simple.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Nothing about Stu, in the end, is really important enough to justify the Sturm und Drang of Phone Booth or its tempest in a telecommunications teapot.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a slight story enlivened by good acting, crisp pacing and some graceful comic touches.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The reason it works is simple: Farrell.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Short, suspenseful, funny, and profane.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What keeps Phone Booth going, despite its premise, is the acting and the writing, both of which are top-notch.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A tense little sketch of a movie that catches you in a vise grip of tension and trickery.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Farrell delivers a tour de force in this clever cross between Sweet Smell of Success and Dog Day Afternoon.

item.label: rotten
item.content: So choppily assembled none of the various clues and innumerable suspects ever seem to lead anywhere.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The case is crazy with clues, fights, new characters who fail to detain the attention, and all-important tapes containing something or other. The resolution is rubbish.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mr. Reynolds has appeared in a long string of stinkers in recent years, but this time, the trouble isn't his fault.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The problem is that there is no chemistry at all between Reynolds and Russell; they stand near each other and speak words of emotion, but there's not much light in their eyes and they don't budge the needle on the romantic voltmeter.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A showcase for Russell's amateurism, the director's ineptitude and the screenwriter's clogged pen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Aronofsky, who has parlayed this movie's Sundance success into two Hollywood deals, is that rare indie filmmaker who doesn't want to make hip romantic sitcoms. He's a genuine experimenter with a spooky visual style.

item.label: fresh
item.content: We share Max's feelings of imminent psychological disintegration as the film probes our own insecurity in the face of the eternal. Maths meets millennial doom in one of the decade's true originals.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's remarkable to what extent Aronofsky has rendered the cerebral kinetically intense. The film's imaginative, diverse images create a mind's-eye urban claustrophobia.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Audacious and bursting with ideas.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie's low-budget look neatly matches the claustrophobia of Max's life, but the filmmakers have also devised some special shooting methods for certain scenes. These sequences -- breathless and jangly chases, for the most part -- look terrific.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As smart as it is, 'Pi' is awfully hard to watch. Filmed with hand-held cameras in splotchy black-and-white and crudely edited, it has the style and attitude of a no-budget midnight movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Transports us to a world that is like yet unlike our own, and, in its mysterious familiarity, is eerie, intense, and compelling.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It all leads to a very strange place, and I'm particularly impressed with the economical means, both financially and artistically, by which Aronofsky gets there.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The seductive thing about Aronofsky's film is that it is halfway plausible in terms of modern physics and math.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pi turns what should be a metaphoric relationship into a stupefyingly literal-minded thriller.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A picture so original in style that it sometimes seems downright peculiar.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bresson choreographs the complex techniques of lifting wallets and watches with such precision that one seems to be watching a kind of surreptitious ballet.

item.label: fresh
item.content: French director Robert Bresson used his nonactors only once and orchestrated every gesture and glance; the performances that resulted are both mesmerizing and suffused with mystery.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bresson's goals were deep; to sweep away the dross of expectation and viewing conventions by means of a purified cinema. At times in this thief's journal his visual discourse touches the sublime.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ultimately inexplicable, this concentrated, elliptical, economical movie is an experience that never loses its strangeness.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Bresson films with a certain gravity, a directness.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pickup for the most part falls flat on its face and borders on presumably unintended, comedy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Sam Fuller, who wrote it and directed, appears to have been more concerned with firing a barrage of sensations than with telling a story to be believed.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Perhaps finally flawed by its overt political assumptions, but the film remains a desperate kind of masterpiece.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Spottily effective.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This horrific tale is told with marvelous shadowy indirection and delicate lyricism.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The result is little more than a discreetly artistic horror film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The story provides Mr. Weir with material for a kind of Australian horror-romance that recalls Nathaniel Hawthorne's preoccupation with the spiritual and moral heritage of his own New England landscape.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A film of haunting mystery and buried sexual hysteria.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One of the most hauntingly beautiful mysteries ever created on film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Spottily effective.

item.content: This horrific tale is told with marvelous shadowy indirection and delicate lyricism.

item.content: The result is little more than a discreetly artistic horror film.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Aniston] has the rare gift of getting you to root for her in the most trying of circumstances, a quality that will stand her in good stead when she progresses to better material.

item.label: fresh
item.content: [Aniston] at her best can recall young Barbra Streisand in her What's Up, Doc? days.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Aniston doesn't need dialogue to catch Kate's quicksilver moods. It's the sitcom lines, at the service of a contrived plot, that choke her.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Insubstantial and oversweet, it still refreshes as a midsummer brain cooler.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Aniston comes across like an imitation of a movie star instead of the real thing. She gets less attractive as the film goes on.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's a shame the plot is so contrived, because parts of this movie are really pretty good.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What Picture Perfect sells as romance is a junior high school health class morality lecture we all got years ago. And it was a crock then, too.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There are times when a bad ending doesn't seriously damage a motion picture. This is not one of those.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A wild-eyed, everything-in-the-pot cross-processing of artistic, cinematic, political and personal concerns, where the story stutters, splinters and infuriates its way to an explosive finale.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The result is repetitive and precious rather than inventive and fresh.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Unmissable.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I once wrote of it as \"Godard's most virtuoso display of his mastery of Hollywood genres,\" I now see it more as the story of silly characters who have seen too many Hollywood movies.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The screenplay by Brian Hohlfeld incorporates three of the original Pooh stories but captures none of the charm of A.A. Milne's droll voice.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A flimsy flashback-ridden tale about the importance of friendship, loyalty and the notion that size doesn't matter when it comes to tackling seemingly insurmountable issues.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Bother! Or, rather, why bother?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Fiedler brings his trademark high-pitched squeal to the beloved, childlike Piglet. The other voice actors are just as good, with each one providing great heart and verve for their respective characters.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even those with a soft spot for Pooh won't find much to like.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a wonderful Piglet? Maybe not wonderful, but still pretty darn good.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Sure it's slight, but also as cute as the curly tail on its tender protagonist.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Screenwriter Brian Hohlfeld imbues the animals with the easily recognizable foibles and insecurities that have made Milne's stories (and the films adapted from them) so endearing through the generations.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is harmless fun for the kindergarten crowd, but even they will notice that the Blustery Day video they've been playing at home is a lot better.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Piglet, the gosh-darned cute sidekick of Winnie the Pooh, manages to carry this warm and fuzzy animated feature on his wee shoulders.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I suggest you get out the books, which for once can truly be said to be more spectacular than the movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Speaking as someone who has not visited the planet of Milne in decades, I was pleased to return to a place where words such as 'eureka' and 'aha' are central to the vocabulary: expressions of discovery and affirmation.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In the knockabout world of animated movies, Piglet's Big Movie is an oasis of gentleness and wit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With his typical charm and grace, Piglet proves again that great things can come in small packages.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Poor Piglet doesn't gets his due on Pooh Corner, nor does he in this movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Parents may find their attention wandering, but the simple tale contains valuable life lessons for their youngest offspring, who will likely be enchanted.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There are sweet turns that make the journey worthwhile.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Not only an exquisitely revolting satire, it is also Pasolini's most fascinating piece of cinema.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This isn't one of Pasolini's greatest films, though it's possibly the one that today best shows the warp and woof of its period.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Pillow Talk is a sleekly sophisticated production that deals chiefly with s-e-x.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It often seems complacent and shallow.

item.label: fresh
item.content: One of the most lively and up-to-date comedy-romances of the year.

item.label: fresh
item.content: But there's still time for a gloriously unexpected coda, a moment of quiet reflection and narrative ingenuity that confirms 'Pineapple Express' as the finest comedy of the year.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Watching Pineapple Express is like sitting dead sober in a room with a bunch of stoned people who are laughing uproariously. They're having a great time. You're not.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Gore and yucks are not an easy combination to pull off and Team Apatow simply do not have the skills.

item.label: fresh
item.content: At its sharpest, the script by [Seth]Rogen and Evan Goldberg, who co-wrote Superbad, recalls what made Superbad worth seeing: the sidewinding conversational riffs, the why-am-I-laughing? wordplay.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is an endearingly slovenly, profane movie with bursts of startling violence, but it's all played for nyuk-nyuk laughs, and it has been directed with more care than it might initially appear by David Gordon Green.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Never generates any big laughs, and the chase elements are so intentionally cliched they never take on a life of their own.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Imagine Superbad, but with fear of drug-related homicide replacing adolescent sexual panic as the excuse for male bonding, and you won't be too far off.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The swath of destruction these boys leave in their wake seems disproportionate to the prevailing mood of dopey fun.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This by turns inspired, goofy and finally weirdly hyper-violent celebration of male bonding and chronic Peter Panism joins such classics as Up in Smoke and the Harold and Kumar oeuvre in its sunny, raunchy acceptance of its own idiocy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Apatow and Green are just throwing whatever they can at the screen, to see what will get either a laugh or a grimace. More likely the latter, since you'll likely leave the theatre wondering if you saw a comedy or a Sam Peckinpah movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A comedy that brings a nicely deflating note of realism to action-film mayhem, as well as being one of the few drug movies you don't have to be high to enjoy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a funny, mostly harmless and entertaining film with a bad case of dry mouth.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie is so wayward and fuzzy that, for the unbaked, at least, there's very little pleasure to be had in trying to follow it. The thing is so desultory and aimless that it seems like work to try to laugh at it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The movie's too long -- and the violence and mayhem are unexpectedly harsh and heavy -- but Franco's inspired, looped performance is right up there in the annals of reefer filmdom with Jeff Bridges' the Dude in The Big Lebowski.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This one takes the action comedy to places -- irresponsible, violent, and funny -- that it has never been before.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The sloppy script (which Rogen co-wrote) aspires to nothing more than old Cheech and Chong routines, built around frustrating, circuitous conversations.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Frequently hilarious, occasionally sweet and often graphically violent, Pineapple Express may not be the greatest stoner movie ever made, but it will do perfectly well until we get another hit of Harold and Kumar.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It is the laziest sort of action comedy, with lumbering chase scenes, a dull-witted script and the charmless pairing of Mr. Eastwood and Bernadette Peters.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An overlong, undercooked action comedy made out of retooled parts from other film vehicles.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's little that's new in the material, and nobody seems to have asked whether the emotional charge of blatant racism belongs in a lightweight story like this -- even if the racists are the villains.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's weightlessly, irredeemably enjoyable.

item.label: fresh
item.content: While the film now looks primitive and even more amateurish, it is laudable, if that's the right word, because unlike most movies being made these days, almost everything that happens in it is absolutely, horrifyingly real.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Waters works best with some restrictions on his license. He's much better as a subversive than he is an anarchist.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I am not giving a star rating to Pink Flamingos, because stars simply seem not to apply. It should be considered not as a film but as a fact, or perhaps as an object.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Vivid, revealing and emotionally intense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The results are uneven, though fitfully interesting.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Pinocchio is a substantial piece of entertainment for young and old.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The charm, humor and loving care with which it treats its inanimate characters puts it in a class by itself.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It still is the best thing Mr. Disney has done and therefore the best cartoon ever made.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Probably shows Disney's virtues and vices more clearly than any other cartoon.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The moral lessons include a literalization of metaphors about lying and other forms of misbehaving, and the grasp of a little boy's emotions and behavior often borders on the uncanny.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Was there ever a scarier, more exciting animated feature than Pinocchio?

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you're looking for signs of intelligent life -- well, did you really expect to find them in a remake of a Seventies B-movie anyway?

item.label: fresh
item.content: This moderately entertaining popcorn thriller recaptures the B-movie spirit of such vintage schlockmeisters as Samuel Z. Arkoff and Roger Corman.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An awe-inspiring, stomach-churning journey into blood, gore, and boobs directed by one of France's most talented horror auteurs, Alexandre Aja.

item.label: fresh
item.content: That most unlikely of remakes -- an improvement.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What is disturbing is the talent and distinction of much of the cast, whose mere presence seems to signify an element of smart, self-conscious fun that the movie does not really supply.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A movie this adolescently dirty-minded could hardly pass up a chance to go to Lake Titicaca.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's hard to imagine how scenes of mass dismemberment set during a wet T-shirt contest could be staged any better.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A bloody entertaining blast of a flesh-eating fish-out-of-water story.

item.label: rotten
item.content: [Tries] so hard for the laughs and the allusions amid all the gore, and endless bloodbath of bare naked ladies, that it completely forgets to frighten anyone.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Aja serves up the tongue-in-cheek thrills, CGI-enhanced gore and gratuitous nudity with such unabashed relish that this may prove to be the summer's break-out horror hit.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Here -- in a Jerry Bruckheimer-produced high-seas adventure that incorporates roaring cannons, oddball comedy, a love story and more than a touch of the supernatural -- Depp unleashes his theatrical bravado. He's hilarious.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Depp invests this overfed, action-tractioned swashbuckler with a voluptuous wit and spry spontaneity it surely doesn't deserve.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Buries its treasures -- mainly Johnny Depp in eye shadow and dreads as Captain Jack Sparrow -- in briny cliches.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An awkward pirate epic that's jampacked with energy, ambition and spectacular effects.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This movie is far too long.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pirates steams ahead on a mirthless course of script beats and busy action sequences, coldly steered by director Gore Verbinski to the boom-blast-blare coordinates of producing commodore Jerry Bruckheimer.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Isn't so much a pirate movie as it is the idea of a pirate movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Certainly, Pirates has its moments. But it's definitely no 'E' ticket.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An overstated, unashamedly silly summer adventure.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There is much by way of noise, computer-generated action, big sets and breezy laughs, and practically nothing to intrude on your thought processes afterwards.

item.content: Who knew Johnny Depp was a theme park all by himself?

item.label: rotten
item.content: A monotonous, repetitive spectacle of endless shipboard sword fights and pirate ghosts in the moonlight.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Just imagine spending two hours-plus on a Pirates of the Caribbean ride and you'll get some idea of the approximate sensations that this movie creates.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An improbably entertaining, if overlong, adventure that brings new meaning to the term 'summer camp.'

item.label: fresh
item.content: A theme park ride has been successfully transferred to the screen.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Mind-bogglingly, there's virtually no swordplay for the first two hours; when Keith Richards shows up for his soused cameo, the visual joke hangs in the air.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Advice to Johnny Depp fans: enjoy a seafood dinner, skip the beginning, and roll up after half an hour. You won't have missed a thing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The entire franchise seems on the verge of collapse, propelled to construct ever more grandiose flights of fancy. Without those sequences, there would be nothing there -- but a movie cannot exist on rollick alone.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The plot is not only hard to follow, there seems to be nothing real at stake. Half the characters are already dead, and half the movie seems to involve swordfights with dead people who can't be killed with swords.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Not so much thought out as strung together -- colorful incident upon colorful incident, but without logic, gathering suspense or any attempt to establish emotional connections between audience and actors.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Depp descends into the shallows of self-parody, and the plot, keen to tie up every narrative loose end, manages to be simultaneously expansive and incomprehensible.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Worth seeing for the jaw-dropping action, the doses of irreverent humor and of course the star power of Depp, Knightley, Rush, Orlando Bloom, Bill Nighy, Chow Yun-Fat and a host of other talented actors who utter their lines with Shakespearean gusto.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A glazed, inhuman, cluttered piece of work, a storytelling mishmash that buries the considerable charms of its actors under heavy drifts of silt.

item.label: rotten

item.content: [I]f Precious has a crucial flaw, it is that it is at once too bleak and too hopeful in its closing scenes: too bleak in the history it unearths, and too hopeful that the mere fact of the unearthing will make that history go away.

item.content: I just returned from the immediate future, like two minutes from now, and I have a strong feeling I'm about to give this movie a big thumbs down.

item.label: rotten
item.content: So there you have it: go to church, keep your husband's gaze averted from stray blondes, try not to think about the future, and all shall be well.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Confusing, convoluted and yet gripping and emotional almost in spite of itself Premonition is the first movie Sandra Bullock has successfully 'carried' in years.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The script could have used some analysis itself. After proceeding for an hour in its fairly obvious supernatural path, suddenly the movie decides to get religious.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The sloppy, absent-minded Premonition is a step back in time and a giant leap backward for Sandra Bullock.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Premonition is an odd little thing, with a protagonist in a protracted fugue state and a plot that doesn't know whether its coming or going.

item.label: rotten
item.content: At least all this uncertainty is leading up to a spectacular twist ending -- oh, wait. No, it's not.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I have a premonition you won't give a damn. I sure as hell didn't.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The psychological thriller Premonition is neither as beguiling as you might hope nor as moronic as you might fear, floating comfortably in that gray, maybe-we-can-get-it-from-Netflix territory.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The convoluted setup doesn't produce a payoff worthy of the attention this film demands.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Premonition works hard at wearing out its welcome, with numerous scenes that don't seem to add up and too many characters who feel underwritten.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Somber but soulful, Premonition has a strong dramatic performance by Sandra Bullock and a gimmicky plot that doesn't grate until the end.

item.label: rotten
item.content: When we get to the top of the roller coaster, the film stalls and slows down.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It never pays to think too much about movies constructed to make you think.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Premonition, for all its far-fetched nature, never lets go of its momentum and holds the audience every inch of the way.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Premonition is both dreary and absurd, suffering from a lack of intrinsic logic and terrible pacing, a one-two punch that kills off any chance of entertainment value.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Premonition maintains a chilly grip on the viewer, almost in spite of the spotty storytelling.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pay real money to see this feeble fiasco only if you're in the mood for Groundhog Day without the laughs.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Honed to a riveting intensity by director Alan Pakula and featuring the tightest script imaginable, Presumed Innocent is a demanding, disturbing javelin of a courtroom murder mystery.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In a welcome return to suspense, Pakula effectively conveys the claustrophobia of domesticity and courtroom procedure.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Mr. Ford, who comes alive in the flashbacks recalling his tempestuous affair with Carolyn, spends much of the film with a wary, cautious expression masking all other emotions. He does this with flawless delicacy...

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ford -- breaking again from his Indiana Jones heroics -- is astonishingly fine in a performance of controlled intensity.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An engrossing adult drama that relies on complex characterizations and twisty plotting, and doesn't ask us to accept its central character as a superman.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The adaptation of Turow's novel does a good job of presenting the evidence as needed, and no more than is needed, while allowing time for the characters to establish themselves.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Competent, resolutely unflashy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A solid whodunit.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: To be able to give this kind of stuff new and sympathetic twists is a tribute to Hughes' skill with narrative, and to Ringwald's magnetism as a performer.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Miss Ringwald's pouty naturalness remains her biggest asset, and her performance is once again appealing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film is strongest when focusing on the two perfect-foil leads as they blissfully indulge paranoid fantasies about poison in the local water supply and plot covert counterespionage operations.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like any good study in couple's psychopathology, a familiar relationship is visible here, but in a parodic, mutated form.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This is old-fashioned, assembly-line moviemaking without the old panache.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Pic's casting is astute, with Gere underplaying like a sturdy ballet star who hoists the ballerina Roberts on his shoulders.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For a film that attempts to satirise snooty materialism, it focuses too pantingly on the designer labels, and comes down firmly on the side of 'rich is better'.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It is something special.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.content: Pretty Woman seduces all but the most wary.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: What's peculiar is that the film doesn't build toward anything because even as the boxing careers flourish, the character of Arturo drags everything down.

item.content: The specificity of Glory's setting and the ethnicity of its characters enrich the story without moving it one iota away from a mainstream frame of reference.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Cliches fly faster than fists in Price of Glory, an old-fashioned boxing movie that can't really go the distance.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie clocks out with a cowardly sucker-punch.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Price of Glory is not a contender.

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gary Oldman is excellent as Orton, right down to remarkable resemblance, while Alfred Molina creates both an amusing and tormented Halliwell. Vanessa Redgrave takes top honors, though, as a compassionate and benign agent.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Oldman is brilliant; Molina's Halliwell less subtle; and the film's dissection of cottaging quaintly amusing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The film covers the main events of the Orton life in a manner that is nothing less than distracted. One has little understanding of the fatal intensity - and need - that kept Orton and Halliwell together.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The great performances in the movie are, of course, at its center. Gary Oldman plays Orton and Alfred Molina plays Halliwell, and these are two of the best performances of the year.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The filmmakers have shown great intellectual taste. But it's not the kind of taste that's illuminating.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Like \"Casablanca,\" \"Diva,\" \"Clockwork Orange\" and countless other quality-cult films, \"Prick Up Your Ears\" has an indefinable idiosyncrasy that makes you want to come back for more.

item.label: rotten

item.content: Keira's cat-smile suggests such supernal all-knowingness that, with Austen's adapted dialogue (via Deborah Moggach) tripping off her tongue, she comes off as an eighteenth-century Maureen Dowd.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Dare I say that even Jane Austen herself would have delighted in the final triumph of Ms. Knightley's quick-witted Elizabeth in this film? Yes, I do, and all the highbrow and middlebrow cinephobes of the world be damned.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I just feel like I've seen this so many times.

item.content: This Pride and Prejudice isn't minutely faithful to the book -- and for good reason -- but it is authentic where it counts: to the confused, wounded, eager hearts of its lovers.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: What it lacks in subtlety and intelligence it makes up in violence, brutishness, and hackneyed story lines. These are qualities best enjoyed at home.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Bloody, violent and increasingly derivative, 'Pride and Glory' betrays its initial promise as a small-scale, 'Godfather'-esque social tapestry with crude plotting, variable acting and an all-too-guessable storyline and conclusion.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's yet another movie about familial strife in the New York City Police Department. If you think you've seen it all before, you have.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pride and Glory is full of interesting little grace notes, and the cast is excellent, yet it grows more and more frustrating. It has everything going for it except a story that doesn't send the audience out miles ahead of the plot developments.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pride's only saving grace is Edward Norton, whose mere presence raises the level of a film several notches. But it's unclear why he lately has chosen such worn-out material.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There's nothing really wrong with Pride and Glory, apart from an excessive degree of brutality, but there's nothing terribly revelatory about it either.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An unexceptional police drama that doesn't live up to its high ambition, Pride and Glory feels like a television cop show that made it through one season before disappearing.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What makes the characters in Pride and Glory real -- and raises the movie above the standard corrupt-cop fare -- is their capacity to live and die in shades of gray.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's bearable for two acts, but eventually sensation overtakes sense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Pride and Glory, directed by Gavin O'Connor, plods across familiar ground. It's yet another movie about the fraternal disorder of the police.

item.label: rotten
item.content: When the writers went to the Dialogue Store, it must have been closed because they loaded their cart from whatever they found in the Dumpster out back.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The dirty-cop drama Pride and Glory overshoots the mark by spinning its implausible, hyperviolent tale around too tight a family circle.

item.content: Even the weakest episode of TV's The Shield owns Pride and Glory outright: This is the kind of movie so relentlessly derivative, you can figure out the turns and surprises awaiting in the script just five minutes into the story.

item.content: A plodding, formulaic police drama bathed in bluish light, Pride and Glory displays very little of either.

item.label: rotten

item.content: Primeval is one of several recent movies to bill itself as 'inspired by true events.' So was this review, though in both cases 'inspired' may be too strong a word.

item.content: How capturing an animal found in every zoo constitutes a scoop is beyond me, but when you expect the trio to be knee-deep in blood they are instead wading through politics.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What a croc! Unsolicited advice to filmmakers: When making a monster movie, do not attempt to sell said film as a picture about a serial killer.

item.content: It's difficult to think of a worse horror movie than Primeval, partly because it's barely a horror movie at all.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten
item.content: As usual, the talent in Prince of Persia is generally top notch -- from the cinematographer John Seale to the parkour expert David Belle -- but the ingredients have been masticated so heavily the results are mush.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A spectacularly silly video-game adaptation about a Fresh Prince of Gel Hair who runs around the desert with a magic dagger, a curious version of Alfred Molina and some hoity-toity chick who never breaks a sweat. It's sort of pointless.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Prince of Persia is destined to disappear into the quicksand of time, too innocuous to be hated, too bland to be remembered, just awaiting some bright optimist in a distant future to press the do-over button.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This movie is little more than a big noise bomb with jerky movements attached.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Don't think too much about its main prop and plot device -- a magic sword that can turn back the clock and change history -- and Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time is a fun ride.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: Prince of Persia, a movie born of a video game, is at war with itself, and the bad guys win.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Although Prince of Persia stimulates the circulatory and nervous systems, it engages none of the higher faculties of game play. Like, say, hand-eye coordination and map-reading skills. It's a frenetic yet passive experience.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Prince of Persia got the go-ahead from an administration at Disney that was sent on its way last year. I wouldn't be surprised if their successors at the Mouse House wish they had a magic dagger that would allow them to go back and erase this movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie is too cheerful and earnest to motivate any active dislike toward it, but not good enough to warrant any strong praise. It's the reason shrugs were invented.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The funny thing is that Gyllenhaal, with his boyish charm playing nicely off his buffed-up physique, actually makes a pretty decent action hero. If only we could go back in time and make Prince of Persia worthy of him.

item.label: rotten
item.content: All of the action and mayhem is designed to distract the viewer from the realization that a lot of what transpires during the course of this movie makes little sense.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What's missing in Prince of Persia is a sense that all the running, jumping, climbing and fighting is leading to something. The best video games challenge you to reach the next level. Prince of Persia is content to skim the surface.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh
item.content: Rosemary Dewitt is fantastic.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's a successful experiment that leaves you with a mix of hope and despair. To the lovers, best wishes. To the lonely, our sympathies.

item.label: fresh

item.label: rotten

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Rachel Getting Married is at its best in scenes featuring Hathaway's mercurial character. It's a triumphant and darkly nuanced role for her and a departure from the more lighthearted comedic performances she has given.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A minor work, but so menaced by distress that the characters take every opportunity to dance the dark away.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Rachel Getting Married has the sense to recognize that it only takes one lunatic to throw a family gathering out of kilter; this is not an exercise in competitive crazy like last year's irritating Margot at the Wedding.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film is Demme-esque, harking back to the darkness and emotional complexity of The Silence of the Lambs and the madcap energy of Something Wild.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's Hathaway's extraordinary performance that is the film's brightest accomplishment.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Rachel Getting Married is a portrait of a family reeling with pain and resentment -- and rising to the challenge of dealing with it head-on.

item.content: No longer is Rambo killing for a cause, but for kicks. And his portentous blather, even by Rambo standards, becomes unintentionally hilarious.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"So they send in the devil to do God's work,\" says a hulking Australian mercenary, part of the rescue attempt. \"It's ironic, isn't it?\" Highly ironic. The implications of that irony are not explored in the movie.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A grim, hyperviolent send-off that could give you post-traumatic stress disorder.

item.content: This violence contains a movie, but only intermittently.

item.label: rotten

item.content: If bringing back Rocky and Rambo opens him up to more ridicule from the likes of me, ita(TM)s also the kind of challenge at which he excels. Idiotic as Rocky Balboa was, the punches landed, and Rambo works on its own debased terms, too.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The enemies so comically monstrous and their deaths so gory, that you may just throw your head back and roar with laughter.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Rambo hits his stride in the film's second half, meting out justice in an unjust world and ultimately the movie works best when warbling its out-of-tune greatest hits.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's an unfortunate ending for a once-great screen character who deserves to be known for more than the waste he laid to others.

item.label: fresh

item.content: None of this is beyond what you'd expect -- or fear -- from a Rambo movie. What is inexcusable is the moral self-congratulation the movie trades on, attaching itself to the plight of the Burmese people.

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten

item.label: rotten
item.content: The body count is rising, Sly's pecs are blowing up, and Rambo himself is becoming more of a brand-name than a character, a mascot for masochism and murderous self-assertion.

item.label: rotten
item.content: To anyone who doesn't share the camera's adoration, this sort of behavior becomes so comic that Rambo turns into something of a camp classic.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Flooded with warm light and a radiant mood, Ramona and Beezus is a sunny series of charming escapades and subtle flights of fancy that capture the safe fusion of imagination and reality where all little girls should grow up.

item.content: Director Allen, whose previous film was the uninspired mermaid saga Aquamarine, tells the Quimbys' story gracefully. She elicits remarkably honest performances from her younger stars.

item.content: This new Ramona prefers mischief without real edge. You always know her parachute has a silver lining, even in an economic downturn. She is, above all, safe. And that makes her nowhere near as entertaining or enduring as the girl on the page.

item.label: fresh
item.content: \"Ramona and Beezus\" is a small-scale story of life and learning, of setbacks large and small and triumphs major and minor. It is neither dark nor dour, but it also does not kid itself about the messy realities of life as part of a family.

item.content: This all sounds like uptight, grown-up nitpicking, probably. But it's also a reflection of a weakness in storytelling, which is sad given the strength of the source material.

item.label: fresh
