item.label: fresh
item.content: A CGI western comedy populated by desert critters, Rango gives the film year a belated jump start with a passel of movie-wise fun and a knockout animation style.

item.label: fresh
item.content: With his first animated feature, Pirates of the Caribbean director Gore Verbinski shows ambitions considerably beyond producing the usual standard of most children's fare. To put it plainly, Rango is one weird movie.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Yes, [there are] enough nods to other sources to make Rango a bobblehead. But the movie, and much of John Logan's writing, is still pretty durn clever.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The best of Rango is a lot like the best of the first Pirates movie -- crazily funny and rambunctious.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What elevates it above a cheeky romp is the skilled CGI work, not only the wealth of tactile detail lavished on the parched townsfolk but also the painterly, sand-swept vistas they call home.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Rango's not just a kiddie-flick (though it has enough silly slapstick to qualify as a pretty good one). It's a real movie lover's movie, conceived as a Blazing Saddles-like comic commentary on genre that's as back-lot savvy as it is light in the saddle.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An ultra-quirky animated Western with a vocal tour de force by Johnny Depp that's quite unlike anything I've ever seen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A sun-baked symphony of rust and dust, Rango has a spiky, unsentimental appeal, sending out slightly risque jokes to parents while staying safely out of the danger zone for kids.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The whole enterprise is redolent of past movies (and drug trips), yet it somehow whiffs fresh.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The film itself is a magically strange hybrid, a spoofy computer-animated Western acted out by anthropomorphic desert creatures.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It is not self-conscious knowingness that drives Rango but rather a quirky and sincere enthusiasm for all the strange stuff that has piled up in the filmmakers' heads over the years.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Every other week, it seems there is some new creation full of fantastically realized creatures engaging in eye-tricking action. The ironic effect of this... is a so-what-else-you-got state of jaded exhaustion. And then along comes Rango.

item.label: fresh
item.content: I've made a good case for seeing \"Rango,\" and why not; an eye feast is still a feast in this lean multiplex season.

item.content: Its virtues are still plentiful: Kurosawa's visual style at its most muscular, rhythmically nuanced editing, and excellent performances.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Much of the power of the picture -- and it unquestionably has hypnotic power -- derives from the brilliance with which the camera of director Akira Kurosawa has been used.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Kurosawa's most brilliant move in Rashomon is never to reveal what really happened. We are left to make our own deductions.

item.label: fresh
item.content: What Kurosawa implies in this haunting film is that in the retelling, inevitably every man will make himself out to be the hero or villain of the story.

item.content: Would it be redundant - or too premature - to call 'Ratatouille' the best film of the year?

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: Ratatouille doesn't center on the over-familiar surfaces of contemporary life. It harks back to Disney's older era, when cartoons seemed part of a more elegant world with less edgy characters.

item.label: fresh

item.label: fresh
item.content: From the moment Remy enters, crashing, to the final happy fadeout, Ratatouille parades the brio and depth that set Pixar apart from and above other animation studios.

item.label: fresh
item.content: How good, and how much fun, is Ratatouille? So good that when it was over, all I wanted to do was watch it again.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Sarah's Key,\" based on the novel by Tatiana de Rosnay, struggles with a problem it never overcomes: How do you make viewers care about everyday problems when juxtaposed with the horror of the Holocaust?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Excellent performances make the movie effective. Yet the flashbacks have a depth and resonance largely absent from the modern scenes.

item.label: fresh
item.content: While the flashbacks come to life through small acts of courage and kindness amid epic-scale evil, the frame story is a recurring letdown that feels trivial and contrived.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Sarah's Key\" cuts back and forth between a tragic story involving the Holocaust and an essentially trivial, feel-good story about a modern-day reporter. It's an awkward fit and diminishes the impact of the earlier story.

item.label: fresh
item.content: In an eloquent, moving manner, Sarah's Key argues that we are all products of the past regardless of whether we are aware of it and that understanding our roots, no matter how painful the process, is preferable to remaining oblivious.

item.content: This Elmore Leonard-style noir about lowlifes versus dirtbags is nasty, vicious fun.

item.content: \"Savages\" makes you wonder where Stone, that most pointed of directors, is going. And then it never gets there, backing off at the last minute. As such, it is literally a brutal disappointment.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It all feels more like flexing atrophied muscles rather than creating a believable experience.

item.label: rotten
item.content: \"Savages\" is a juvenile fantasy of bullets, breasts and bongs -- not such a bad thing, if Stone would just admit it and stop staging the film as a profound ethical wrestling match.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Complain as loudly as you like about Oliver Stone - his politics, posturing and relationship with the facts - but until now he hasn't directed a film that's flat-out dull.

item.label: rotten
item.content: While Savages aims for provocative and dynamic, it comes off as predictable and strained.

item.label: rotten
item.content: You might not think that a motion picture called \"Savages\" could be too violent, too savage, but you would be wrong.

item.label: rotten
item.content: How did this film end up with such a muddled story?

item.label: fresh
item.content: The playful way Stone flips the mood demonstrates a command of the material he hasn't shown in more than a decade.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As teen melodrama, well, Carter's film is what it is; but for such a mainstream black-consciousness movie, at least it doesn't shy from addressing some touchy issues about masculinity, parenthood, and black attitudes to whites.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A refreshingly friendly view of a romance between people of different pigmentation, an area where more respectable pictures still wimp out.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Whatever happened to wanting to dance simply because it's fun?

item.label: fresh
item.content: Stiles and Thomas supply what this movie needs most: a heartbeat.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It pays knowing respect not only to high school social politics, but also to racial politics among today's young people.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The intent is a feel-good film, sort of an American version of Billy Elliot and I didn't believe a minute of it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Squanders nice performances by Julia Stiles and Sean Patrick Thomas by confining them and the supporting cast to cookie-cutter roles and hackneyed inner-city subplots.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The high school repartee has snap, crackle and pop, but the romantic drama is strictly cornflakes that have been left in the milk too long.

item.label: fresh
item.content: An admirably heartfelt story with more on its mind than the glory of self-expression.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Predictable teen-dream drama.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Stiles and Thomas are good together, in a warm and fuzzy, as opposed to hot and heavy, sort of way.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A decent, well-put-together romantic drama to hold hands to on the weekend.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This movie would sooner see Derrick help Sara fulfill her Juilliard destiny than acknowledge how hard he worked to get into G-Town. It's profoundly square screen writing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This skin-deep MTV Films production is more about promoting soundtrack sales than social causes.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The playing of ballet against hip-hop gets more than a little corny, but the charismatic young performers make the corn work.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Recycles every cliche of the genre to sleep-inducing effect.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For all its dumb cliches it offers the basic appeal of teen movies: the pleasure of watching kids be kids, acting as they do among themselves instead of how parents and teachers expect them to act.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The setup promises cliches, but the development is intelligent, the characters are more complicated than we expect, and the ending doesn't tie everything up in a predictable way.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A spirited, dirty dance between the polished inauthenticity of Hollywood romance-musicals and hip-hop's central tenet: keeping it real.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's far from tepid teen fare, thanks largely to the sweet chemistry between up-and-comer Sean Patrick Thomas and leading lady Julia Stiles.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saving Grace has a lovely Cornish setting and Blethyn to recommend it, but mostly it's a contact mediocre.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Blethyn's solid-gold charm turns Saving Grace into a comic high.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Frothy, silly, ever so slightly subversive and purely delightful.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Beautifully shot on location with sure comic timing by director Nigel Coles, Saving Grace is a real high in a season filled with unfunny comedies.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It has two great British landmarks: champion actress Brenda Blethyn and that wonderful rugged Cornwall coast. All that's enough for a temporary high.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A modestly effective comedy.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Saving Grace has a charm that keeps you involved throughout.

item.label: fresh
item.content: There is nothing profound in this movie, but it shines through so many of this summer's dumb Hollywood comedies like a beacon through a haze of smoke.

item.label: fresh
item.content: It's funny and charming most of the time, thanks to Brenda Blethyn.

item.label: rotten
item.content: We're left with a promising idea for a comedy, which arrives at some laughs but never finds its destination.

item.label: fresh
item.content: After an uproarious first half, Saving Grace arrives at its conclusion somewhat hastily and conveniently. But to its credit, it still maintains a sunny comic mellow.

item.label: fresh
item.content: This is a less-showy performance than the ones [Blethyn] gave in those other two movies, for which she was nominated for Academy Awards, but it's just as impressive.

item.label: fresh
item.content: No further commentary is needed when the raw brutality of combat is presented as indelibly as it is here.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I found it tediously manipulative despite its Herculean energy.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Why did Spielberg make it? He wants us to imagine we can feel the terror of being there, but does that make us any wiser about this or any other conflict? Probably not.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The greatest Steven Spielberg movie since the last great one? Sure.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A powerful and impressive milestone in the realistic depiction of combat, Saving Private Ryan is as much an experience we live through as a film we watch on screen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: For those who are willing to brave the movie's shocking and unforgettable images, Saving Private Ryan offers a singular motion picture experience.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A war film that, entirely aware of its genre's conventions, transcends them as it transcends the simplistic moralities that inform its predecessors, to take the high, morally haunting ground.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Feels like the first truly honest attempt to deal with the horrors of combat - and the terrible responsibility shared by all survivors.

item.label: rotten
item.content: For all the care and thoughtfulness that follow in the story, I never could shake the impression that all I was watching was every other war film Spielberg had ever seen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Gripping and satisfying in a way that no mere summer event movie could ever be.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Launches and climaxes with two of the greatest extended battle sequences ever put on film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Using the overpowering techniques of modern film, Steven Spielberg has cut through the glory-tinged gauze that shrouds World War II to reveal its brutal reality, creating a phenomenology of violence unsurpassed in the history of cinema.

item.label: fresh
item.content: As compelling, intimate and brutally realistic an account of men at war as you've ever seen.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Spielberg has captured the hair-trigger instability of modern combat.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A soberly magnificent new war film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Has 'masterpiece' written all over it.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Spielberg has taken us back to basics -- back to art, back to amazement at the film medium itself.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Saving Private Ryan is not a film that one takes pleasure in, or even enjoys in the usual sense, but rather, it's a movie that elicits a hushed admiration and an uneasy appreciation.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A flawed but masterful film.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A powerful experience.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This full-throttle sophomoric comedy still feels forced and phony at times, which undercuts the manic efforts of its cast.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Dugan ... encourages one and all to be as frat-house gross as possible.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A relentless misfire, ineptly stealing from a number of crude but more ably executed comedies.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The script ... smacks of desperation beyond saving.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Despite an early, zesty deluge of gags ... it soon settles down to an anxious man-a-thon.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Expends a moderate budget and several attractive young performers to absolutely no consequence.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Not just stupid, but brain dead.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Overall it's desperately in need of rescue.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The movie can barely muster the bravery to be even Dude, Where's My Car stoopid.

item.label: fresh
item.content: A sublimely idiotic farce.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It is frantically, bizarrely unfunny.

item.label: rotten
item.content: How bad is Saving Silverman? This is a movie in which a man is shown getting butt-cheek implants.

item.label: rotten
item.content: There is nothing in the personalities of J.D., Wayne or Darren that makes me believe that they don't deserve to be slapped upside their heads for being pathetic losers.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If Judith ... were asked to render a diagnosis of what's wrong with Saving Silverman, she might note that it displays a pathological fear and hatred of women.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Someone ought to call the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Actors.

item.label: rotten
item.content: In a fun house like this the elaborate tortures seem to leave behind the real world of pain and suffering for the realm of slapstick; they're the kind of horrors that make you scream and laugh at the same time.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Quite possibly Saw II sheds enough blood to satisfy horror aficionados.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As it was in the first Saw, audiences are faced with insane leaps in logic that sabotage the last part of the film.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw II only has one ambition -- to make us squirm. And it does. Just don't be surprised if you need to switch to an electric razor after this.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw II -- better-acted than its predecessor, which isn't saying much -- is so gratuitously, sadistically violent, and to such little end, that it finally falls over dead on the far side of obscene.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Saw II has teeth, and this house-of-horrors franchise has legs, though they're manacled to the radiator.

item.label: rotten
item.content: At the very least, with Saw II, you get what you pay for.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The serpentine plot is logical; the acting is passable and the film creates a palpable atmosphere of paranoia and tension.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even hard-core horror can go too far. Saw II is as punishing as it gets. It's effective, all right, but to what end? Certainly not entertainment.

item.label: rotten
item.content: I saw Saw, I saw Saw II, and I have lived to tell about it. Aren't you glad?

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw II lacks quite a bit of the cutting edge that made the original such a guilty, grisly pleasure last year.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The makers of Saw II have taken great pains to hide the twist ending to the film. I'd love to reveal it out of spite, only because it hints that I'll be sitting through another Saw sequel next year.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw II goes to great lengths to be smart and not just viscerally but intellectually provocative. An admirable ambition, but it just makes the movie even more silly when it fails so utterly in the effort.

item.label: rotten
item.content: No point in labeling this a horror film. This is a sadism film, and while all good and great horror films know what sadism tastes like, a sadism film settles for nothing of lasting, imaginative horror.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw II is not for the faint of heart. It's for the foolish of wallet.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What's worth noting is how much greater deliberation was given to the marketing than the screenplay of this cursory dud, rushed to theaters exactly a year after its amusing predecessor.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The most horrifying moment is saved for last: when you realize things have been obviously set up for yet another sequel.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Essentially, this is one more movie that, regardless of its setting or even planet, exists to knock off its cast members one by one.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The second Saw sequel develops the mythology of sadistic puppet-master Jigsaw in ambitious, gruesome but ultimately self-defeating ways.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Admit it: It's not every horror film that can make you feel preached at and slimed at the same time.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Tedium eventually sets in again, the movie's murky visual schema and overly aggressive editing style marring any attempts at subtlety. Worse yet, the Jigsaw Killer remains a smug, unscary bore.

item.label: rotten
item.content: More gore is really all III has to offer.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Just like its increasingly wan antihero, this blood-soaked series is on its last legs.

item.label: fresh
item.content: The question for moviegoers: Would you rather get your dose of existenz-philosophie from Dostoyevsky or a slasher flick?

item.label: rotten
item.content: Do you want to play a game? How about a really long, convoluted game that leads nowhere? The scariest thing about Saw III is how it seems like it's never going to end.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Ee'll just entertain you by mentioning such extraneous details as a human skull being opened and probed, a naked woman being frozen to death, a man drowning in the ground-up carcasses of dead pigs ...

item.label: rotten
item.content: The premise is bogus to anybody with all their albumen intact.

item.label: rotten
item.content: As the creators of The X-Files learned and the people behind Lost are going to find out soon, you can only jerk around an audience... for so long before they start screaming in frustration and move on to something else.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A bigger problem lies with Leigh Whannell's script, which utilizes so many flashbacks and explanatory inserts that the tension, a defining feature of the first Saw, is lost.

item.label: rotten
item.content: What's remarkable about these movies is how much the craftsmanship degrades with each episode. This is a long, scrambled, indifferently made affair. There's no rhythm to the sequencing.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw III is duller than a plastic steak knife.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The inevitable deadening effects of repetition are beginning to infect the Saw franchise, now having produced its third installment in as many years.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw III, with its barrage of grungy rooms, mortified flesh and elaborate torture, is a highly creative exercise in bloodletting, with a bleak view of human nature.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw III was not prescreened for critics. It doesn't need to be. The midnight preview I attended last night was packed with folks who don't mind seeing Hollywood beat a dead horse.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The reports of torture porn's demise may have been greatly exaggerated, but this fourth entry in the mutilate-yourself-or-die series joins what may be the worst genre of the decade: the lamely ''sympathetic'' serial-killer backstory.

item.label: rotten
item.content: This death trap may be rusty, but as long as it keeps generating fresh blood, it's unlikely to slam shut anytime soon.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Just as Jigsaw tests his victims, the franchise's own test will be whether such suspension can be maintained, or if matters lapse into a torture chamber of self-parody.

item.label: rotten
item.content: An incomprehensible cacophony of screams, shock cuts, dour pseudo-philosophizing, heavy metal mutilation and low-rent TV-standard performances.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The Syriana of slasher films, so complicated and circuitous that your only hope of understanding everything is to eat lots of fish the night before and then watch each of the previous films, in order, right before you enter the theater.

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's somewhat better put together than Saw II or III, though there isn't a scare in it.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The famously inventive torture sequences here seem depleted of imagination.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The original Saw was crafted with thought and precision. Saw IV is an orgy of blood.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The dullest Saw in the shed.

item.label: rotten
item.content: A film as edgy as a rubber knife.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw IV is no Saw III. Just as Saw III is no Saw II. But neither Lionsgate, the Saw distributor, nor the North American box office seems to care.

item.label: rotten
item.content: After two solid entries and an OK one, the franchise is getting long in the tooth: This one is Saw It Be-IV.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Easily the worst and most pointless episode of the gore-saturated quadrology.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Over the course of [its] sequels, the Saw franchise took a novel, if distasteful, idea and basically tortured it to death.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even fans of good, old-fashioned, onscreen torture will find themselves rolling their eyes at the twists and turns in this impossibly convoluted story.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The need to incorporate familiar characters and icons from the earlier films, together with flashbacks that flesh out Jigsaw's pre-'puppet master' past, simply leads to an irritating series of creative dead ends. Truly, a hack-Saw.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw V is a terrible combination: grisly and tedious. Let's just call it bloody dull.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Even the most die-hard of Saw fans won't credit how tedious, lame and pointless this fourth sequel manages to be.

item.label: fresh
item.content: Saw V isn't anywhere close to the best Saw movie, but it makes the entire series coalesce a little bit better.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Woefully ponderous, convoluted and improbable.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Oh, Jigsaw. Here we go again. You kill. I doze off. Someone at the studio goes 'ka-ching!'

item.label: rotten
item.content: The latest and least of the Saw films is just plain boring and even a little tame -- albeit by the standards of a genre that helped bring the phrase \"torture porn\" into the lexicon.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The periodic traps set for five new victims, all linked by a rotten real-estate deal, are neither as terrifying nor as yucky as in the earlier films. The only real horror in these scenes, in fact, is the jaw-droppingly bad acting on display.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The creatives behind the franchise clearly have taken pride in their stylistic consistency throughout the series, but here they even fail to deliver enough of the cleverly gruesome Rube Goldberg torture devices that are its raison d'etre.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw V is dead on the table.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Thank goodness Lionsgate made another Saw film! Otherwise, how would we as a country get to feel good about ourselves while watching humans suffer through prolonged torture, degradation and death?

item.label: rotten
item.content: It's not a good sign when watching someone stick their hand into a table saw is easier than listening to them recite dialogue.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The torture devices, once so fiendishly adapted to each offender, have become generic excuses to spatter gore. The script is insultingly lazy, and inept direction from newcomer David Hackl hardly helps.

item.label: rotten
item.content: Saw V utterly mimics the original film's formula -- that awful basement, those cops chasing clues in what we assume to be the same time-frame, those awful devices of death.

item.label: rotten
item.content: If you haven't followed the series up until now, there's not much point in trying to catch up.

item.label: rotten
item.content: The usual critiques apply: terrible acting, zero suspense, laughable logic and the promise of another one next year.

item.label: rotten

item.content: The Saw series long ago cannibalized its cleverest bloodbath gimmicks, but now it's figured out a new way to torture us: by taking a barb-wire stab at political relevance.

item.content: Who knew that the franchise's creators would eventually find a plot twist that made sense?

item.content: These movies lack a whole lot of panache.
